element_texts.text: Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill
April 4, 1921
Dear Mum & Grandmum 
Thought I would surely get this written yesterday, but had so many "irons in the fire" didn't get around to it. Malcolm and Max spent the day with the Westerns so I had planned a busy day for myself. Malcolm wore his velvet pants and silk waist and they looked fine - as well as any I could have bought I think. Many thanks for the 2 bundles of comforts which arrived the other day. The booties are lovely and
Completed

I am sure Tunsilu will be much pleased with them. The nightgown is very nice and will be a help to the nurse since it fastens down the front. Started a crib comforter yesterday. Expect to make 2, and with the other coverings I have now, will be well fixed.

 Read the clipping you sent about Fannie. I can imagine the Park was in a state of great excitement during the trial and may not recover for some time. Hope it all ends favorably for Fannie and that
Completed

(V enclosed)
she may continue to hold the P.O. job. 

 Our telephone was put in last week. Number is 285- R. Seems nice to have it. Gives one a certain feeling of security.

Had the dining-room rug beaten Saturday by a forlorn looking tramp who said he spaded our garden last year. Did a good job on the rug.
Do you want me to return the clippings regarding
Completed

regarding the trial? 

  Nice and warm yesterday got up to 78º and may go as high today. Pieplant now shows in all of the places where it is planted. Max is getting some shrubs today to set out in the path of the pedestrians over the lawn. 
  Walked over to look at the new houses yesterday they will probably be done by May 1st.
  So sorry about G.M's blisters. Must have hurt dreadfully. Have not been to se Lillian T's sister. Don't walk now any more than I can help.

Much Love,
Katharine
Completed

M.M. Moore Art Department  K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. Moore
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
April 11, 1921
Dear Mummie,

 Missed sending your $5.00 last week so will send $10.00 this week either Thursday or Friday.
 Continue to feel well except for a few pains occasionally which I believe to be false labor pains, as described in your nursing lectures. Did a big washing Friday and have just finished washing up kitchen floor this morning. Hope to keep on with all my work until the day arrives - believe I will be better off by doing so. 
  Blanket arrived O.K. Many thanks. Have fixed it in the crib. It is heavy enough to cover the oilcloth over the mattress and will do nicely for Tunsilu to lie on. Then can use the other blankets to cover over him-her. Washed some of the baby things that needed it and have fixed the wrappers with new tape for tying and have sewed small clasp fastener at the neck, which will be handier than the safety pin and looks better. Am going to make spread
Completed

for the crib out of one of my old bed-spreads. Made a sofa pillow cover of some of my left-over curtain cretonne yesterday - to have in the bedroom. 

 Our early spring has been seriously threatened last few evenings. Had snow Saturday night with temperature of 25º.  Warming up today however and snow was all gone by noon Sunday.
 Max has painted all screens and put some black enamel on the kitchen stove which is great improvement. 
 Got a letter from Laura saying that she might drive out with Norine in Laura's Ford Tuesday afternoon if weather is pleasant, so am looking forward to seeing them.
 Have not heard from Helen for several weeks. Presume she is very busy moving. 
 Malcolm & Buddie have just come in each armed with a bunch of dandelions. Spring flowers are out but have not been down to pick any as it is too far for me to walk.
 Hope you both are well and that the heat will not make you miserable. Seems hard to realize that it is so hot at noon there, but I know the worst is yet to come.

Much Love,
Katharine.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department
K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.
M.M. Moore
Photo Pillow tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL
April 14, 1921
Dear Mum:

  Enclosed find $10.00 as suggested in my previous letter.
  Had a very pleasant visit Tuesday from Laura and Norine, also Laura's mother and sister Grace. They drove out in the Scott's Ford and arrived about 1 o'clock, bringing their lunch with them. They had a big loaf of bread, some cheese, boiled ham, pickles and cookies. I furnished chocolate cake, canned peaches and coffee. After lunch we sat in the living room and talked (had a fire in the grate) and afterwards took a walk around the block and went through one of the new houses at Park & Hillside. They left at 4 o'clock.
  Made a lovely pie yesterday out of some of our own pieplant. This is the first gathering of the season. Noticed yesterday that the sweet peas are coming up. Very tiny so far but have hopes that they will thrive. Want to get some more planted in a sunnier place. Those two bushes make the east side almost too shady. Discovered the Montessori hand-
Completed

handbook on the top shelf in the back row, so all is well.

   Got the toilet basket trimmed yesterday   Found quite a sizable piece of white voile left over from my graduation dress - more than enough for the purpose. Cut two round pieces for the bottom of the basket, putting a layer of cotton batting between them - then gathered a long straight piece of the goods and sewed it on to the round piece Then tacked the upper edge to the top of the basket. Am recovering pin cushion with same material. Scrubbed basket out with soap and water first as was quite dusty. While doing the trimming visited with Dorothy Curtis who is looking after Mrs. C's household (Mr. C, Wendell, 4 boarders, herself & 2 babies) while Mrs. C. is in Arkansas visiting with Esther, who has been on the Lyceum all winter and expects to return very soon. Wendell came home for the Easter holidays, and refused to return, saying they were too strict (it was a military school) so he is now in the eighth grade here. 
  Yes, Mrs. Bacon recovered. Have not called on her nor heard anything of her lately.
 Malcolm wore the black velvet trousers, pongee blouse, black patent leather slippers and short socks when he went to North Chicago and looked quite like the Boul. Miche. Sam was there and the rest of the family. Mrs. Western sent me some
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.

jonquils, 1/2 doz. eggs, some birthday cake and cookies - also a little of the chicken which they had for dinner. Malcolm enjoyed his outing very much. 

  Do not see any signs of Buddie's stealing, but he always asks Malcolm (generally in a stage whisper) to request something to eat. Whenever I hear him I always tell him to go home if he is hungry. (He usually stays).
  Buddie is looking quite well but is no bigger around than he used to be and is relatively no taller when beside Malcolm though of course he has grown.
  Time for postman so must put this outside.

Much Love, 
Katharine
Completed

M.M. Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL,
April 21, 1921
Dear Mum & Grandmum 
Lovely weather again. Pleasant change after the snow last Sunday. Malcolm has the mumps. Caught them from Carl Feist. The Feists make me mad  - They are so unconcerned about children's illnesses. Never have a doctor or let people know what the children have - guess at it themselves and let it go at that. 

 Carl was up here one evening after supper, sitting in the lawn swing with another small boy. Max was working on the car near by, and Malcolm was playing in the swing with the other boys. Max turned around after a while and said - "Why, is that you, Carl? I didn't know you, you look so funny." Carl replied - "I'm just getting over the mumps" (I noticed then that his jaws were swollen. He had been reported as sick in bed, but though I had questioned Malcolm & Buddie repeatedly, had never been able to find out what the matter was.) Max and I then indignantly ordered Carl off the premises. Later
Completed

Mrs. Feist came up and said not to worry; that Carl did not have the mumps but it was some trouble with his teeth that caused the swelling.

  But yesterday when I was passing their house she called out to me inquiring how Malcolm was. He was taken that morning and she should have had no reason to suppose him sick. I told her he had the mumps and she remarked that she supposed he had caught them from Carl!   It was about two weeks previous that we had sent him home.
  Malcolm is not very ill. Is up and around today. Slight fever yesterday afternoon and evening. In bed from 3 p.m. yesterday to 8:30 this a.m. Am hoping he will be fully recovered by the time Tunsilu arrives. Called the doctor yesterday on the phone who gave me a few instructions as to open bowels, keep him warm, etc. 
 Buddie has been sick since Friday. No swelling, but fever most of the time so Mrs. F. says. Says does not know whether he has mumps or not. Mrs. Kopp says the children in the Schoenfeld house also have it - just getting over it. No attempt at quarantine or publicity for these diseases, I think the doctors are very lax and the parents send the children to school without troubling themselves to find out whether they are sick or well, on whether the
Completed

period of precaution has elapsed - or whether there is any such thing. 

  Sent my washing to our local wet wash laundry This week. Had 30 lbs. cost me $1.70. Will be glad when I can do it myself again.
  Have picked out May 1st for T's birthday. Then we will have three "firsts" in the family.
  The cherry trees are in bloom and the apple trees will be some time this week. Buds are all out - quite pink & smell very good. Mrs. Kopp's flowering currant is out. Have a sprig on the library table with some cherry blossoms.
   Someone will wire you when there is any news.

Much love
Katharine
Completed

M.M. Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
April 29, 1921.
Dearest Mum & Grandmum:
Tunsilu has not yet arrived so perhaps it will be a May baby after all. The longer it is put off, the more I can accomplish, so no harm done. Mrs. Lang has completed her work with the other case she had in April and is now awaiting my summons. 

  Am making a couple of bedspreads for the crib out of some old ones that can no longer be used on the big beds. The white crepe cloth that you wrapped one of my bundles in (it was part of a nightgown, I think.) I have made into two slip-on blouses for Malcolm to wear with his overalls. Have bound the neck with bias seam tape, and they fasten in the back with one clasp fastener. Am trying to replenish his wardrobe as much as possible so he won't run out of clothes while I am laid up. Have ordered a new pair of overalls for him from The Fair - some that I saw advertised for 89 cents. Have also ordered a wash dress and white sateen
Completed

petticoat for myself so will have something to wear when I get up. Have ordered a nursing shield from Sears such as the one which gave such a good service when Malcolm was little, and also a nursing bottle, such as he used for water. 

 Max has been busy planting flowers the past few days. He put in nasturtiums, bachelor buttons, an elephant ear bulb, asters, and portulacas (the seed on the shelf you had saved). Has dug a couple of small beds on the west side of the house and planted the rest in the garden in the rear. My first planting of sweet peas is about 4 inches high. Put some others in the ground along the front porch which have not appeared yet. Max has set the geraniums out that were in the flower box all winter, also the amaryllis and begonia. No signs of blossoms yet on any of these. Has planted morning glory seed in the box, which is to rest on the porch rail and the m.g.'s to climb up from there.
   Malcolm's mumps are on the wane. Swelling scarcely noticeable now. Dr. says will not give them to any one after two weeks have elapsed. He is out-of-doors most of the time. Was unable to eat fruit while he was at the worst - says in the dictionary that acids cannot be taken - but
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.

M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
he ate an orange this morning, which indicates he is on the mend. 

 Lilies of the Valley are coming out; and most fruit trees have blossomed. Have had some hard rains the past few days which have been hard on them. 
  Am enclosing article by Percy Hammond which may amuse you. I thought it quite clever. Also send copy of Line which appeared in last Sunday's Tribune. I cut out all of the comments and reprints of poems which appeared when BLT died and am preserving them in the McCutcheon cartoon book where we have a number of Tribune clippings. Do not know who Pa Z is but he seems to hold up his end pretty well. Do not see the Tribune on Sunday. Have the News week days. Need not return clippings. 
 Discovered a fine recipe for Pie Plant pie in the "52 Sunday Dinners" book. It calls for 3/4 cup sugar, 2 tablespoons flour, a little nutmeg and an egg, all to be mixed up and added to the pie plant. Was timorous about trying it at first as it seemed so strange to put an egg in, but have made several
Completed

and all have turned out beautifully. It does away with excessive juiciness and tartness, and is very excellent. The pieplant was not hurt by the frost and has grown very fast so have all I need. Do not know which clumps the tramp set out or transplanted but there is so much out there it must have grown all right. 

  Margaret and Austin moved yesterday to a small cottage in St. Charles on the river near Pottawottamie (is that the way to spell it) Park. Mrs. Miller wanted to sell her place and the new folks, who bought it, moved in right away. Mrs. Kopp knows who they are - forget the name. Have two small children - the mother is about my age. Shall miss Margaret very much. They expect to return and look for a winter dwelling in the fall. The only alternative to the St. Charles move was to live with Mother Flett, so M. will be more contented this way. Her baby is growing nicely and cries real tears in a very pathetic manner.
Had a ride in "Ole John" last Sunday. Pretty windy and too cool for comfort. The robins have a nest in the ash tree - same place where they built in 1915 when we first come out and Puss-cat demolished the eggs. Glad they have decided on this spot so Malcolm can watch them. 
  Will send news when there is any. Feel real well so far. 
  So sorry Billy had to go back. Will write Elsa. 

Much love
Katharine
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.

M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
May 4, 1921.
Dearest Mum & Grandmum:
Tunsilu Moore is not yet with us in person. Each day I have looked forward to as a possible family birthday, but not so. I only hope he (she) will not put it off so long that I can't have Mrs. Lang. She expects to be called by another patient on or near the 15th of May, so in case the other lady is on time, I may only have her help for a few days. I probably can get someone who will do as well to finish out with, though, and the first few days are the most important. 

  Keep forgetting to tell you that about three weeks ago, on a Sunday, Helen and Herman, with the children, also Helen's father, stopped outside in the auto for a few minutes to say Hello. Helen came in for a short interval - long enough to go the bathroom. Uncle Geo. leaned forth from the car and said: "Where is your mother, K?" Then - "Give her my love when you write." He is all smooth shaven, now, and
Completed

his face is quite full. Seems quite well. Do not know what he is doing just now. Have not heard from Helen since and do not know whether they are entirely moved or not, but presume they are. At that time they had already transported all of the furniture that was not essential to their existence. 

  This is our first pleasant day for several days - temp. 62, but much warmer in the sun - cool wind. Has been very cloudy, and as cool as 36º at night with a daytime average of 44º.
    Malcolm is entirely over the mumps now. Perhaps it is just as well that I waited so as not to catch them. 
  An agent came to the house yesterday with a vacuum cleaner, selling at 44.50 cash, $49.00 on time, with a 24 foot cord, reaching very handily from the kitchen plug to all parts of the front room. He left it for a 2 day trial. Will be back tomorrow. Do not know yet whether I will take it or not. Looks something like the Hoover. Have my rugs nice and clean now, anyway. 

xxxxxxxxxx
Continued Thursday
No change in Tunsilu's plans this morning. Am enclosing V as usual and
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
am wondering if shall be sending it off in the customary manner next Thursday. Hope the child will be on the outside by that time. 

  Have put up my washing for the Wet Wash. I live from washday to washday as it were, always hoping to be confined after the clothes are safely ironed, so as to have plenty of clean things on hand. 
  Am finishing Malcolm's second pongee blouse which I have been putting off for more important sewing. Have made up a supply of boracic acid and believe everything is all ready. 
  Have decided not to keep the cleaner. It would be nice to have it, but we will be under quite a bit of expense now, and it would be better to wait until our bank account is on the upward grade again. I understand one can rent a cleaner at the local electric shop any time, for 50¢ a half day, which is quite reasonable and used about once a month would be quite a help. 
An interesting series of articles is appearing every Thursday in the Daily News, one of
Completed

which I enclose. At the end of each article, questions are put, the reader being invited to answer them. I think this one is quite interesting and will send others that contain statements that seem unusual or helpful. Need not return clippings. 

  When is Nina's wedding day and is she to be married in Avon Park or elsewhere? Where does her husband live? Believe you told me sometime ago but have forgotten. 
  The mother robin in the ash tree is sitting on her eggs. Am afraid her offspring will hatch out before mine. 
  Must get at my dishes now and then make a pieplant pie. It does not tire me much to do housework, but cannot walk any distance. Have not been down town for nearly a week. 

Much love to both
Katharine
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
May 12; 1921.
Dear Mum & Grandmum:
You will be wondering whether I am really pregnant, after all, as I have still no news of interest. V enclosed. When I first wrote of my pregnancy, didn't I name some date in May as the possible birthday? If so, the first opinion must have been nearer right. Feel better this week than I did last. My washing goes to the Wet Wash again today - perhaps I shall have several more washdays to live through before my times comes. Mrs. Lang's next case is scheduled for the 15th so if her patient is on time I shall have to engage some other nurse. There is a Miss Whitman in Wheaton whom I might secure - and I took down two phone numbers of Chicago nurses that appeared in last Sunday's Tribune which may bring some help - if not, will let the doctor provide someone. The doctor has not tried to get in touch with me at all, so must be he does
Completed

not think it strange that I am going over the time set. The robins nest in the ash tree has suffered a tragedy ocurring yesterday morning, as I was dressing Malcolm. Heard a great racket, and looking out saw a horrible big black crow sitting at the edge of the nest, eating the eggs. About 6 blue jays were in the tree screaming, while this was going on. The robins came back after the rabble had dispersed but they are no where to be seen this morning. Malcolm wept with much anguish for quite a while and I felt like joining him, as we have enjoyed watching the robins very much. Evidently, that is an unlucky spot for nesting. 

Helen dropped in on us last Sunday for a minute or two while her husband and children waiting outside in the car. Says they are all moved now, but does not know what their address is, so if you wish to write her use 5929 West Lake St., which is the number of Herman's store. Everything nice & green - barberry bushes in bloom, also syringa & bridal wreath. Trees all out except catalpas. Lilies of the Valley in bloom. Only one small blossom on the lilac bush in back yard. Hope to have some news before long.

Much love
Katharine
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
May 19, 1921.
Dear Mummie:
Glad to have your good letter and thank you very much for looking up the reference to the birthday. Am pleased to have another date to look forward to. If it does not come on the 26th (a week from today) then I shall pin my faith on June 1st. I wanted it to be on the 1st of the month, anyway. Mrs. Lang said that her other patient had made arrangements with her first so of course has first claim on her. I called her up early in December but she was away, so did not get in touch with her until a little after New Year's Day. Am not worried about getting someone else - am sure I shall have no trouble. Miss Whitman, the Wheaton nurse - will be off duty and in addition I have just learned of a trained nurse (Mr. Chatteron's sister) who is married and lives near 5 Corners. She is anxious to get some local nursing and has had a number of years of
Completed

hospital experience. Am to find out in a day or two through Mrs. Kopp what she charges. Mrs. K. got the information for me through the wife of Mr. Chatterton. In addition to these I have taken down 3 telephone numbers which appeared in the Tribune last Sunday - nurses desiring confinement cases. So these, with Dr. Schiel's help ought to be all I need. So good of you to offer to come. Might send for you in an emergency but otherwise not as I don't anticipate any trouble. Malcolm was much pleased with his letter. Mrs. Kopp has a few baby chickens and he enjoys watching them. 

Awfully warm today. 86 degrees at 3 o'clock. Mosquitos very savage and give promise of being more so later on. Malcolm knows his letters quite thoroughly and draws some of them but not all. He likes to paste pictures in the scrapbook I made him and just now is learning how to make chains out of paper strips. Most of his time is spent out of doors riding down the hill at tops speed in his wagon which he manages with much skill. Lately has had a desire to work in the garden and enjoys digging for angle worms. Digs with the spading fork and takes the harvest to Mrs. Kopp's
Completed

chickens. Glad you have some new furniture. Am sure the desk will be a great help. The pup is quite sizable and looks something as pupsie did. Will send you a picture of him if I ever get around to take some. Will also include some of Malcolm in his "velvet pants." The grocery boy has just brought my things so must stop and do some cooking. We have had one strawberry shortcake so far. Very good. Is it past your berry season? (40 cents qt.) 
Much love
Katharine
Saturday - Have held this up to enclose your $5.00 as did not have
Completed

letterhead on side
M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.

change before. Am finishing this as Max eats his breakfast, so he can take it. No change in the situation so far. Weather very warm. 91 degrees yesterday afternoon. Warm all night - 65 degrees just now. Feels quite refreshing. Dr. Sommerville's new brick house S.W. corner Hillside & Forest is being built. Just across on other corner stucco house nearing completion. Helen stopped in for a minute yesterday to learn news if any.
Much love,
Katharine
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
May 26, 1921.
Dear Mum & Grandmum:
I hate to think of your staying closely at home in anticipation of my telegram, for I am still up and around and feel the same a usual. V enclosed. 

I bid fair to rival Mrs. Lang's patient who expected in Jan. and delivered the latter part of March. At the time she told me of it, it seemed quite preposterous but I am certainly following in her footsteps. Washed my hair again yesterday. This makes the third time I have washed it so it would be clean for my confinement! You spoke some few letters ago of Mooncalf. I should like very much to read it if you a through with it. It is still listed among the 6 best sellers and was so listed all winter. Some of my newer Jack London books are very entertaining and I should like to mail you an occasional volume if you are able to take on any reading matter at this time.
 I have found quite a bit of leisure time of reading during the past
Completed

month. Read the stories by Helen Gardner "Pushed by Unseen Hands" also Bret Harte's "Ward of the Golden Gate" and "Ardis Claverden" by Frank Stockton. Enjoyed the last-named very much indeed. Have you ever read it? All three are books that have sate upon our shelves ever since I can remember. I took two pictures of Malcolm yesterday in his new overalls, wearing one of Max's old straw hats. Will try to get a good one of the dog and some of M. in his velvet trousers, then will send them to you. These are the first pictures I have taken since last summer when we were in Michigan. Have just gotten over the warmest week of weather I have every known in May. It got up to 90 every day and sometimes to 92. Then at night it remained at 75 or thereabouts so we have not had a chance to cool off until last night when it dropped to 64. Is now 68 - 10 o'clock D.S. time.   

Dr. Saunders died about ten days ago - had a Masonic funeral. Diabetes, I think. Have not seen Mrs. S. as stay home all time now. Felt like sending her a congratulatory note but have refrained. Am mailing your calling cards. 

Much love
Katharine
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
June 6, 1921.
Dear Folks:
Tunsilu is a boy! Arrived Sunday morning at a quarter of 7. Max wired you yesterday but the nurse received a phone call this morning to the effect that they could not locate anyone in A.P. by the name of May Walden. Guess they had not tried very hard. I told her to tell them to deliver in care of the post mistress so hope it will reach you before this letter does. The baby is awfully sweet. Has a nice rosy face and is just as perfect as Malcolm was. Still hesitating about a name but hope to have it settled soon. My nurse is very pleasant and capable and willing, so everything is running smoothly. I feel fine and have walked to the bathroom several times.  Malcolm is a most devoted brother and takes much pleasure in looking at the baby and talking to him. He has slept a great deal since his arrival and nurses like an old timer - takes hold better than Malcolm did
Completed

at first and swallows each time as though he were getting something. His bowels have moved quite copiously several times so all is well. His nails were so long that they curled up at the ends and he has more hair and darker than M's. was. 

I had a harder time than with Malcolm on account of some severe pains in my back, but it is all over now, so no use rehashing it. Got my washing back from the laundry and hung up to dry Saturday (Mrs. Kopp helped hang it up.) Then my pains came on after supper - about 8 o'clock. So I hurried up and got most of the ironing done. Max brought the nurse at 10 o'clock. Went to bed at 11 and slept a little between pains until 2. Then called the nurse and had her phone the Dr. who arrived at 3. made an examination and lay down for a nap until 25 minutes of 7. Then I said the head was coming, so he heard me before Max had time to call him and came rushing forth much refreshed & surprised to find that we had let him sleep so long. Then, he gave me chloroform and I didn't know anything for 5 minutes or so, when it was all over, but the child isn't named Sarah.
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
Had no pains with the afterbirth. The doctor showed it to me & explained the various parts. Then he stayed with me about an hour, massaging the uterus and then putting on the bandage. Then went home to breakfast. 

Max and the nurse were a great help to me and really worked hard, rubbing my back and helping to pull and listening to my grunts and groans. Can lie on my back now without any trouble and think it will not bother me any more. Made Malcolm a pair of trousers Friday out of that piece of heavy white goods left over from what I used for his coat when in Florida - purchased at the McGinnis store. The trousers look very nice & are made after the same pattern as the velvet pants, designed to help out with the pongee blouses.
Had a nice cool night for my exertions. Got down to 46 and had to have a fire before morning. Let it go out later in the day. Nurse is going over town now to mail this. I'm sure you will rejoice with me that it is all over with and that Tunsilu is on the outside. 

Much love
Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill.
June 14, 1921.
Dear Folks:
Shall have to break the news that Tunsilu weighs only 7 1/4, or rather that is what he weighed Tuesday last. The following Sunday he had gained 6 ounces - not so bad for the first week. We did not have the scales fixed up to weigh him Sunday when we sent the telegram, so had to guess at it, and he looked so big and felt so heavy (on the inside, at least) that we thought 9 pounds would hit it about right. However, it won't be long before he will weigh much more than that, at the present rate.

He is the best baby yet nursed so well right from the start that my milk came Monday evening. He nurses every 3 hours and usually wakes of his own accord, right on the dot. Don't know yet who he will look
Completed

like. Looks something as Malcolm did but has more hair, and darker - the color of Walden's. Many thanks for the lovely bib, shoes, and pillow case. Shall keep the bib and shoes until he is about six months old, as are too large for him now. Malcolm is much pleased with the pillow case. Did you make the lace, Grandma? The new son has been registered as Marvin Douglas Moore. We decided that Lionel was most too flowery. Got a letter from Margaret in which she said she had not yet acknowledged the booties and was not ashamed to do so after waiting so long.

I remember Mrs. Lewiston very well. I always liked both her and her sister and shall be glad to have her call any time. In writing, you might give her my phone number 285-R, so that she can let me know when she is coming. Will send $10.00 on Thursday as omitted the $5.00 last
Completed

week. Am returning Darwin's picture. He is a very nice looking boy. How old is Altana now? My nurse is a graduate of the Frances Willard hospital and is all that one could wish. Is a very good cook and has made some fine cherry pies and some nice custards since she has been here. The cherries are nearly ripe enough to can. Have had some very warm weather since I have been in bed, but usually a good breeze. Most forgot to acknowledge the alphabet book, which Malcolm enjoys very much. He reads the capital letter on each page and I read the verse. 

Shall probably teach him to read next winter. Helen called on me last Sunday and was much pleased over the baby. They are conducting an icecream cone stand on Roosevelt road near their home as a sort of side line.
Completed

Mrs. Kopp and the neighbor on the east side of her home, Mrs. Mauer, have both brought me flowers a number of times - roses mostly, and one bunch of peonies. Mrs. Kopp sent over 4 cup cakes for our Sunday supper. Have sent announcements to various friends. Mailed one to Miss Ross to the address given in the letter you enclosed. Hope she will come see me when in Chicago. I think she is wise in planning to go to California, as she hates cold weather so. 

The Bentleys have a For Sale sign on their house. The Mrs. has been gone for quite a while. Heard a rumor to the effect that she was mentally unbalanced and that she is in a sanatorium undergoing treatment. If so, it is too bad. She was always so pleasant. Perhaps 3 of one's husband's sisters would be enough to unbalance anyone. Shall go downstairs tomorrow for the 1st time. 

Much love,
Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
June 25, 1921.
Dear Mum & Grandmum:
Having a little rain for a change - mighty scarce so far. Awful hot weather no covers at night - can't even stand a sheet. Marvin doesn't feel the heat. No dress on him and no petticoats. Just shirt, band, dider and booties. 

 Let nurse go home last Thursday, the 12th day. Feel real well. Had Mrs. Dodge in to clean yesterday. Did the whole house except the back rooms in 4 hours. Gets 50 cents per hour. Will have her again for a time or two until I feel like doing it myself. Max did the dishes for me several days after the nurse left, so I had nothing to do but wash the diders, tend the infant, and rest myself. 
 Walked down town yesterday for the first time. Malcolm pushed the buggy most of the way. There is a new meat market - cash and carry - just to the right of the place where I worked for Mr. Kidd - practically the same location that Mr. Turner had for his market when I was a little girl. The proprietor handles vegetables and
Completed

fruits in addition to meat, and it is a saving of time and money to go there. 

 Glad to hear about Nina's preparation for her wedding. Hope her father will come to see her and that Mrs. Marsh may soon be placed in more congenial surroundings, free from her responsibility. Give all the Marshes my love and tell them one of my pleasantest Avon Park memories is the one of my visit with them. Also please ask after the health of the alligator who dwelt in their lake. 
 Virginia Kopp has just returned from a week's camping out with her group of Camp Fire Girls two miles south of here near Bogan's Farm. One night 3 squares of bacon were stolen and another about 4 dozen nice homemade doughnuts which one of the mothers had sent to them. Also; one of the neighboring farm houses caught fire and they helped carry water to put it out - these little incidents relieving the dull monotony of camp life. 
 Uncle Frank has acknowledged my birth announcement and says he may stop in July 2nd, so perhaps we can scramble along without Uncle Charley. 
 Am going to town now with Virginia. 

Much love
Katharine
V enclosed.

July 5, 1921.
Dear Mum:
So hot, am quite late with my letter, but had no inspiration to write before. Plenty to say, but too warm to say it. Has been 95 and even 98 in the shade for a week or more and goes down about to 86 at night. 

  Had a call from Mrs. Lewiston and her two sisters and the husband of one last Sunday (a week ago). They stayed about an hour. Had quite a good chat with Mrs. L. She looks natural as can be. They all admired the baby. Helen and Herman drove up while they were still here. Later in the evening we drove over to their new house for the first time. It is about two blocks east of the place on the State Road where we turn north to drive into Wheaton. They have quite a commodious house, still in process of construction. They are living in it, and gradually completing
Completed

completing it. Herman has just bought a swell new 7 passenger limousine, so must be he is fairly prosperous. They have an ice cream cone stand on the Road as a side line. Guess Herman's nephew looks after it. Helen is real well and quite enthusiastic about their new home. They have some old hens and baby chickens. No other live stock - oh, yes a pig. 

  Had more callers last Thursday - Norine, Laura, Alice (Norine's sister) Mrs. Scott and Grace Scott all drove out in their Ford and dropped in in the afternoon. Norine brought a very pretty pair of booties (the short kind) for the baby and Laura brought a lovely little romper suit (the kind that buttons across the bottom) made of white pique, and beautifully embroidered in cross stitch and buttonholed at the neck and sleeves. Wish grandma could see the buttonholing. Am sure she would say it is fine work. 
  Received the Bradley catalog. Glad to have it. Will order some sewing cards for Malcolm and other things later. What is the process of transferring the
Completed

co-op stock and what payments have to be made? Got a letter form Jo Kaniko. Seems she is working on the co-op magazine. Marvin is fine. Weighs 9 1/2 now. Pretty good for this hot weather. He wears just band and diaper now. We all went down to the community picnic yesterday at the springs and saw the fireworks. Went down at 7 in the evening and came back at 10. Ate our lunch down there with the Kopps. Ever so many people stopped to speak to me and admire the baby. Most of them strangers. Saw the Thomases. Neither of them look well. Mr. T.'s eyes all blood-shot
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
and she is awfully thin and doesn't look at all well. Says she is planning to go to England next fall. Arthur looks pretty well. Lillian said she got a letter from you the day before. She always enjoys hearing from you. V enclosed. Max is on his vacation this week and next. Does not expect to go away anywhere. Jerry has disappeared. Think he may have been electrocuted on the third rail. May turn up later, however. This is his first disappearance. Been gone 3 days. 
Much love

July 16, 1921.
Dearest Mum:
Am sending wringer screws by this mail. Sorry not to have gotten them off before. Had visions of Grandma wringing the sheets by hand, perspiring the while. How does she stand the heat? It is fairly cool today -just 85 now at 4 p.m., but we have had the longest continual hot spell that even the oldest inhabitants have ever seen. Am not enclosing any V this time but will send 3 of them next week. Max is on his vacation and will be paid his vacation money on his return. 

We drove to St. Charles and called on Margaret last Monday. She and the baby both look real well, but Margaret is so fat! Weighs close to 170 pounds. Have never seen anyone get so fat so short a time. Austin has to have meat every day all the year round and this helps - together with the fact that she eats a great deal between meals and hasn't so much housework to do as she had in Glen Ellyn. She says they expect to move to Wheaton in the Fall and will occupy Mother Flett's house. M.F. is going 

upside down:
So glad to see Jack London letterhead and photo. How fine Aunt Ida can be there. Have just finished reading John Barleycorn. If you have not read it will send. It gives more of an autobiography than 'Martin Eden'.
Completed

to England for the winter and may stay thru the following summer. Betty would be a pretty baby if it were not for her funny ears. Margaret is having her wear an ear cap, but the chief trouble is that they have no curl or roll at the upper edge but are perfectly flat with a sharp edge instead of a curve. Do not know that you can get the idea from my description. I have never before seen ears just like them. She has exceptionally pretty eyes, blue - and when her hair covers her ears will look all right. 

Took our lunch Wednesday and with Helen and her two boys, went to the Springs. The springs have been fixed up, covered over with boards, and a pump installed in the one to the right as you go down steps. Water is fine, just as good as ever. Guess they felt it necessary to cover them as most city people found it agreeable to cast their lunch scraps and broken bottles into the water. Tunsilu is fat as a butterball. Weighs 10 1/2 lbs. Pretty good, don't you think? I keep him in band and diaper all the time now and he has expanded remarkably. Could hardly button his shirt last
Completed

M.M Moore Art Department
K.K. Moore Business Mgr.
M.M. MOORE
Photo Pillow Tops
Glen Ellyn, ILL.
night when it turned a little cooler. Papa is in Michigan this week and offered to take us to dinner some time in August. Will invite him out pretty soon. Just heard from him for the first time this week. Said he didn't write before because he knew I would be too busy to answer. I have been taking time to practice some duets with Virginia Kopp, and we both enjoy it. Some of them sound very well indeed.

Malcolm held the baby several times at short intervals the other day. Will try to get a picture of him with Marvin in his arms. He is very nice to the baby, always and I am so glad he has him. He always says "my baby" when he speaks of him. The other day Clara Wimpress came up on the porch to look at the baby. Malcolm was standing nearby and she said (as so many people have said, drat 'em) "I'm going to steal your baby brother and take him home with me." Malcolm spread his arms protectingly,
Completed

over the buggy and said, "Oh, no, you can't because he came out of my Mama's body!" Clara was much embarrassed, especially as Max was sitting on the porch at the time. It will be a long while before she repeats that remark. Fully 9/10's of the people who have looked at the baby have made the same remark to Malcolm and he has countered with various defenses, but this was the first time he ever used the above argument. 

Am mailing the Child Welfare pamphlet. Was much interested in your notes on Child Welfare. Might use my experience with Malcolm in your talk, telling how he expected the baby as soon as I knew we were to have one, and always had in mind something to do for him or make for him. Started many little bits of sewing which were usually "a coat for the baby brother." Told him the doctor was coming to help the baby brother "come out" and would have to stay in bed afterwards to rest, because it was hard work to carry the baby around so long. I cannot think of anything easier than confiding in a child at such a time, but it would be a real task to deceive one, and such a bad investment for the future. Must be time for Marvin to nurse - hear him stirring around. 

Much love,
Katharine
Completed

July 21, 1921
Dear folks:
Quite forgot to acknowledge the lovely little balls, and the letter outfit, which arrived safely sometime ago. Malcolm was much pleased with the letters and I am sure they will be a great help to him in learning to spell. Marvin notices the red ball, which I hang in front of him sometimes. This past week he will smile  and chortle nearly every time I speak to him. Also smiles at Max and Malcolm. He is such a good child - lies awake for such a long time without crying at all and sleeps a long time at night without nursing. Never have to rock him to sleep or bother with him, just put him down and he goes to sleep sooner or later, without any fuss, when he gets ready. 

Am beginning to train him. Started yesterday and saved 3 diapers. It seems hard to realize that he is only 6 weeks old he seems so much bigger than most babies at that age. 

on side:
Anna wants the boy to stay alone after a few days and she will go back to town. Morris looks strong, a little pale, perhaps. Love, Katherine
Completed

Took some pictures of him Sunday. Will send you some when I get them. Called up too late about the St. Augustine pictures. They had already been sent off. Never mind, will see them sometime, no doubt. 

Darwin was certainly well remembered. Must be a very popular boy. What future calling is he fitting himself for, if any?

Mrs. Kopp has just finished a dress for me of yellow organdy with white collar and cuffs. Very nicely made - has overskirt and sash - charged me only $3.00. Am going to shorten the skirt of my graduation dress and wear it. Did it up the other day and looks very well.

Papa is coming out Sunday to pay us a visit. Hope to take a few lessons in chess playing from him.

There is a reporter on the Daily News who has a little writeup nearly every evening, headed by a bit of verse - usually quite clever. I enclose one of his sketches (or her) do not know the gender of the author - If you find it amusing will send others. Do you want John Barleycorn or shall I send some other one of J. L.'s works? Anna Epstein stopped off last Sunday with her husband and boy. They have a ford sedan. 
on side:
Anna and the boy are to stay with the Brunings for a week or more depending on how the B's stand it, I guess.
Completed

Wednesday, a.m.

   8-3-21

Dear Folks:

 Mrs. Dodge is here cleaning the 2 back rooms for me. Have unearthed the nature leaflets which will keep out for Malcolm.
  Your lovely presents arrived on my birthday and everything is so nice. The apron is a perfect fit and the prettiest one I ever had. The handkerchiefs are so pretty,

and my! how rich I feel with so many new ones - and linen, too!  I was quite destitute for handkerchiefs as usual, and I was considering getting a new apron, so
you gave me just the right things.  Many, many, thanks.

 I expect to start doing my own washing pretty soon - perhaps next week. The
Completed

letterhead on side

wet wash does good work but is expensive and I would rather use the money to hire some cleaning done occasionally.  This is only the 2nd time  have had Mrs. D.
She has been sick recently and also is very busy most of the time.

 Malcolm likes John Martins book very much, but I believe it would not pay to give him a subscription to it until he is old enough to read it for himself. There are

so many things in the house already to read to him I would not be able to do justice to any more literature.  Thanks for Tick Mouse book. Have read some of it to him.

 Marvin is fine as ever and such a comfort. Malcolm enjoys watching and talking to him. Is just

beginning to reach out for things.

 Papa sent me a book on chess for my birthday and Margaret sent box of correspondence cards. Several days previous she sent a rattle for the baby.

8-8-21
Monday afternoon
Dear Mum:
Just a brief note, this time, to show you my new correspondence cards, and to enclose 2 V's.

 Will write again later in week. All well. Went to Chicago yesterday in Old John. Met Papa and went to Lincoln Park instead of to Pier as we had planned, on account of
Completed

Pier being so crowded. Big crowd in Park, too. Saw cars with license tags from many different states - one Mississippi. Had dinner at the
Chinese Restaurant at North Ave. where we have been on previous occasions with Papa.  Weather very pleasant. sunshine and cool breeze.

 Marvin plays with his rattle and ball now. Pushes them with his hand and crows.    Love  Katharine
Completed

                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Aug. 15, 1921

Dear Folks:

 Have got books wrapped at last and will mail them this afternoon. Sorry to have kept you waiting so long for them. - We are having a cool August so far.

Is it any cooler where you are? Babe is fine - couldn't be better. As soon as the film in the camera is finished, hope to have some good pictures to send you.

 V enclosed. The neighbors all ask about you both - Mrs. Curtis, Mrs. Feist - Mrs. Kopp and others whenever I see them.
 The house next door on the Pheiffer lot is under way. Basement all done and frame being started this morning. Nearly all the work is being done by 3 of

Mrs. West's grown sons. Very pleasant, hardworking folks, all of them. They gave us a dozen fresh eggs the other day as a token of appreciation for the use of our water
and hose. They have ex-
Completed

perienced some delay in getting their water connections.

 Believe I have not mentioned the cherries, which you asked about some months ago. The crop was very scanty, had enough for several pies and sold one quart

for 50¢ to a neighbor the folks living in Grandma Schoenfelds old house. The birds were thick in the trees all of the time and got whatever we may have overlooked.
I think the worms must be scarce this year on account of the dry weather and the blue jays have been committing all sorts of atrocities - eating baby sparrows alive - etc.
Saw one in the ash tree doing so, and have heard of others.

  Mosquitoes so thick have invested in mosquito tents for all our beds. No trouble now, as the tents are very finely woven and big enough to hang to the floor on all sides.

The Kopps are thinking of getting some. Must be all the mosquitos here have gone over there to escape starvation.

 Glad Nina is happily married. What is Martha doing these days? Dos Spears and family are in town, thinking of building here. Dos sends love.
 Hope have sent the right Whitman book. If you want the other, let me know.     Much love,  Katharine.

on side:
Sent your watch to Frank sometime ago to be fixed. Have not heard from him. Had it insured, so presume he rec'd it.
Completed

                                                                                                     Aug. 25, 1921.

Dear Mummer & Grandmummer:

 X enclosed. Yours just rec'd. Glad books arrived safely. Have just finished reading "This Side of Paradise" by F. Scott Fitzgerald. A very worth-while and

entertaining book. One gets a very wrong impression of it from the book reviews. Got it from our local library which I am pleased to find, has all the
best-sellers always on tap. Got Julius's "Dust" yesterday. Looks quite readable. Have not yet started it. Saw a copy of "Growth of the Soil" on the shelves the other
day but preferred to read the Fitzgerald book first. Have my name on the waiting list for "Main Street". They take your phone number and call you up when it comes in. No such service as that in the Chicago public library and no such chance of getting hold of the best sellers, either.
Completed

Will send for Growth of the Soil for your birthday and have them mail it direct. Hope you will enjoy it.

 Am sending an exerpt from "Queen Victoria" that I believe you will enjoy. Will send the others as they appear.  Same too heavy for envelope on account of X.
 So sorry to hear of Mrs. Durgin's death. The town will not seem natural without her. So glad they showed their appreciation of her and their respect, by closing

up and attending her funeral. Glad to have Nina's address. Will try to write her. Am very busy all the time and never seem to quite get caught up. I don't let the
dishes stack up and I get the washing and ironing done and the diapers kept up to date and the baby bathed and my hair combed - but I do neglect the cleaning.
If I could only go through the rooms and clean some each day, all would be well but it seems as though the days were not quite long enough.  I always read while nursing the baby so have that for my recreation. Also go to movies once a week, while Max
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.

looks after the children. Usually go Thursday evening. Do some baking every other day - pie or cake or bread. Would rather neglect the cleaning than the cooking.
Beds get made once a week - sometimes oftener. Hard to do them with the mosquito tents over them.  Going over town takes quite a while but need the outdoor
exercise so do not omit it unless rainy. Got a nice raincoat and hat for Malcolm from Mandel's (by mail.). Looks fine on him. Going to get him some rubber boots
also.    

 Didn't know you were making Marvin a sweater. How nice that will be!  He is a very handsome baby and looks fine in everything.
 Hope to have pictures of him before long. Getting warm again.  84º just now.
  You will be glad to hear that
Completed

my hair is quite thick once more - thicker than it has ever been I think.

 The new house stands back from the street quite a bit - the living room on a line with the ash tree.  The house is a good 40 feet from our line and does not

interfere with either the light or the view. am rather glad they are building, as it has checked the feet of the populace which were wont to stray over our grass.

 The Kopp's are having their house painted - same color as before. Mr. K. is on his vacation. They all went on steamer Columbus yesterday to Milwaukee.
 Was surprised to learn of Mr. & Mrs. Halpin's difficulties. Do you know which of his children are married? They all seemed so happy when we took dinner 

there that time.

 Got book from library on the Efficient Kitchen. Very helpful. More complete than government pamphlets.
                     Much love    Katharine,
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL

Sept 5, 1921.

Dearest Mummie:

 Have just received an acknowledgement of my book order for you from McClurg's, stating that they did not have it and have ordered it from the publishers to be

sent direct to you. So sorry it could not reach you on your birthday.

 Am enclosing some of the long-looked-for snap shots, which I hope you will enjoy. They do not do Marvin justice - am going to keep trying - but I think the one of

Malcolm in the raincoat is very good. Mrs. Kopp took the ones of myself and the baby.
Completed

Marvin is 3 months old today. Weighs 14 1/4 pounds. Max saw Austin on the train the other day and he said their baby weighs only 15 1/2 now. I'm afraid she
must have been quite sick to lose so much. She is nearly 8 months old. I'm so thankful for Marvin's good health. He smiles so much - yes, he stops to smile
when he nurses.

x x x x x 
 Have just got back from a visit to the ball game. Mosquitos quite thick and Marvin wanted to nurse, so didn't stay long. Met Mr. McNab on the way back. He is

staying with Mrs. Newton. Asked him to call on us.

 Grandma's amaryllis is in bloom. Had 2 big blossoms. One dropped
Completed

off. Put it in a vase and still looks fresh. The plant is in front near the porch - same place it was when you were here.

 The space just east of Orrin Dodge's on Hillside is rapidly filling up. One house is now done and occupied, another is nearly finished and a third is just

being started. They are quite close together. The only vacant space is just east of the Dodge garage - room for one more house.

 Expect to go to library Wednesday and will see about Mrs. Marsh's notice.
 We have  a yellow and white kitten from Louise Ludeke's (she married Fred Binger, did I tell you?) Is still
Completed

in Charley's store. Have not been a ble to determine whether kitten is male or female. Nice little thing and Malcolm enjoys it much more than he did the dog,
because he can carry it around with him. The dog never showed up - gone for good, I fear.

 Malcolm is pretty good about helping around. He doesn't have any wraps to hand up this time of year but is quite good about looking after himself. Can wipe

himself now when he does "big ta" and takes a bath rather creditably, and helps dress and undress himself. Polishes silver for me very nicely and really could
do errands over town splendidly, so far as memory and self-confidence are concerned, but am afraid to let him go yet on account of the traffic, Am planning
to start him in school
Completed

a year from now, if they will take him. do not wish to hurry him, but he is a very energetic lad and must have something to do every minute of the time. Also he is
very big for his age and quick to learn and if he does not start until he is nearly 7, he will be deprived of his playmates and de discontented.  I may change my mind
but that is my present plan. What do you think about it? I expect to teach him the small letters this winter, and to tell time.

 Many thanks for the St. Augustine pictures, which Lillian gave me. Am enjoying the Book Review that you sent. The one on Will Irwin's book and H.G. Wells' 

regarding the next war, is rather terrifying. Hope it will not come until
Completed

my sons are too old to go. If it comes sooner, think we will all depart this section and go into hiding.

 You haven't the right idea about serving the people - I mean, the story hour business and public service in general. They don't appreciate your sacrifices so don't

do it unless you don't happen to need the time for other things, and I dare say there is always something to do.

 Hope Grandma keeps well and happy. According to Frank's usual rate of speed, should judge I can look for the watch back about a year from now.   Must stop now

and put Malcolm to bed. Have been writing this on the installment plan.      Much love  Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Sept. 10, 1921.

Dear Mum:

 Am penning a brief note to enclose X. Hope you got the other one all right 2 weeks ago.   Do not believe you mentioned it in your letter.
  Malcolm was in bed all day yesterday - up and around today complained of a stomach
Completed

ache and had hot water bottle. did not eat anything while sick so guess he will be all right now.

 Marvin splendid. Went without nursing all night last night - from 7 p.m. to 6:30 a.m. Isn't he remarkable. Never cries at night. Goes to bed at 7 without a murmur. 

Never have to rock him. Malcolm has named the kitten Muz (the us has the ooh sound)  
on side
doesn't rhyme with anything I can think of

    Love,  K.

9-10-21
Tuesday A.M.

Dearest Mother:
 Glad indeed to hear that the couch came through all right and that you like it!
  Saw Mr. Schaeffer this morning (the one who did the crating) and he said he had gotten his money all right, so you c an see the freight people forwarded his share to him.
Am enclosing receipted bill for the upholstering. you will remember that you gave me $10 00 toward it and the rest is a

on side:

Enjoyed Mrs. Cleaver's letter.
Completed

present from me.

 Max is leaving his present job on the 15th as the firm is on its last legs. The man under whom he has been working is trying to get him work with one of his friends,

a man who makes covers for automobile tires.

 The house is being painted. I finished the porch floor and the front end rear steps and Max is doing the rest. Worked on it a week ago Sunday and last Sunday.

It is dark
Completed

when he gets home now that Daylight Saving is over with so have to depend on Sat afternoon and Sunday work.

 Have written to Frank asking how he is. Would write or wire one of his friends but cant remember the names of any of them.
  The paint for the house is mostly cream with dark green for the narrow border around the windows (the part that was previously black.
Woman's Club begins today so will cash my check.  Good thing I have it.    Many thanks!
Completed

It is nearly time for me to get Marvin. Most forgot to thank you for the lovely knife you sent him. He was delighted with it and very proud to have it. Both knives that
were given with the shoes which we purchased in A. P. have disappeared.

 Went to town Saturday to do a little necessary shopping. Bought material for one comforter - 10 yds at 18 c (cotton chalis) trousers for Malcolm and shoes, cap for 

Marvin, this stationery and some kotex. Quite a dissipation.           Much love    Katharine.
