                                                                                                     Sept. 20, 1921.

Dear Mum & Grandmum: -

 Very rainy weather. Hung clothes out yesterday. Rained most of the day and part of the night - also more this morning so instead of getting drier they get wetter.

Mrs. Curtis and Mrs. Kopp are enjoying the same experience.  V enclosed.

 Helen Franke is here. Came yesterday to look about and try to establish kindergarten. Is planning to get a room somewhere and remain several months, supporting

herself by kindergartening or caring for children. Her husband has gone west on business and is to be gone for a time - probably until November. They are
thinking of moving west if he can get located.

 She was out here for the first time a week ago to try to get a room, but did not succeed so will be here temporarily. Has the back dining room for
Completed

sleeping quarters. She is very pleasant and we get on very well. Malcolm likes her - calls her Aunt Helen.

 Sam is still in Detroit. Have not seen him for nearly a year, though he dropped in on Max at the office a couple of months ago. Martha is still with Stella, and probably

will be permanently.

 Nellie Zay is in Clintonville so far as I know, looking after a distant relative who is a semi-invalid, keeping house for her. Heard from her shortly after my birthday when

she sent me an apron. She said she was planning to return to Muskegon soon.

 Many thanks for the book reviews. There are many clever things in them. Has your book come yet? If not, will write McClurg's and find what matter is.  The Bentleys

have moved to Rogers Park. Their house is offered for sale. No buyer so far.

 Marvin and Malcolm both fine. Sun is now coming out. Played at the show last Friday evening. Mr. Bowdoin said I was improving wonderfully. (Think he was trying

to kid me)  However. I did do well considering
on left side:
the amount of practicing I get done.  Left Mrs. Marsh's notice with the
on right side:
library lady  Hope she can get in touch with someone who is congenial.

  Much love,   Katharine.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Oct. 1, 1921.

Dearest Mummer:

 X enclosed.
 Helen left for Chicago this morning. Has to meet her husband and talk things over with him. Has given up idea of having kindergarten, but believes would like

to spend winter here as governess. In fact has had an offer of a position from a Mrs. Sturges who lives on Hillside Ave. at Mt. Clair, in that big house on the
north side of the street. Plenty of customers who need her for several hours each week to take care of children, so either way could make her way.
Kindergarten would not be successful because of high rent, in winter especially, because of coal, and janitor service. Could hardly charge more than $5 00
per month for each child and could not do justice to more than 20.

 Guild Hall has been renting for $4 00 a half day and other places proportionately, so you see it wouldnt pay.
Completed

Had such a pleasant morning last Monday when Malcolm and I went to visit the first grade at Main Street school (Hill Avenue) Frances Crisler's room. She
is a wonderful teacher. The children learn without knowing it and there is something doing every minute, so they don't have time to get bored or restless. They sing
little songs and learn to count by means of pictures, and play games and learn the sounds of the letters by cards which she holds up for them. The room is
nicely furnished - piano, little chairs with rubber tips, colored pictures of Mother Goose characters - then colored pegs for each child to count with and colored
chalk to draw pictures. It is all very ideal and Frances is the best of all. The children are so fond of her and she helps the self conscious ones by standing beside
them, and holding their hands while they recite or sing or tell stories. Each child does all these things alone before the class. I think it is such a splendid thing, as
it gives them confidence and does away with embar-
Completed

assment. Especially the singing alone is so good, as any false notes are corrected in the beginning. They all sang surprisingly well by this method.

 Had Marvin sitting up yesterday. wore the white sweater Malcolm wore the time we went to Florida. Made him look quite mature.
 Arthur was over yesterday to play with Malcolm. They are leaving for England in about 3 weeks, his mother said.
 Forgot to say how much Malcolm enjoyed the school. Didn't want to come home, and wanted to go the next day. Am going to try to have Frances over for lunch

as soon as I can and cultivate her acquaintance. Of course, I knew her years ago when I used to come out here to visit Bertha and Hazel, but there has been
quite a lapse of time when I have only seen her once in a great while.

 Enjoyed your description of the new hen house. No wonder the neighbors all come to see it. Must be quite a remarkable affair. Your ice box is fine too. Glad you

have one, as you need it so badly during the hot spells.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.

Ice up here is 20 c for 25 lbs. Yours is quite cheap. How long does 100 lbs. last? I use 75 lbs. per week during hot weather, but often the box is empty all day Monday.

 Have had no frost yet but temperature has been as low as 45 early in the morning. Lots of sunshine, however, so warms up during the day.
  Had a call from our new neighbor Mrs. West the other day. Brought me some lovely flowers from her garden at Westmore (they have not moved yet - house will

not be ready for a month or more). Dahlias, pinks, some fluffy brownish red flowers I don't know the name of and a lovely stalk of gladiolas.

 My nasturtiums are growing splendidly now that the frost is about to come. Ask grandma if she thinks I could dig some of them up and keep them in the house   

awhile. Read in the paper that one should pull up tomato vines and let green tomatoes ripen in the cellar.

  Much love,  Katharine
Completed

Tuesday.

 10-11-21

Dear Mum:

 Have been awful busy trying to do some house cleaning. Yesterday went to town with baby. His first trip on the train.

Bought Malcolm some shoes, had his hair cut and got self a camisole.
Completed

went in on fast train at 1:07 and came back on 5:05. Am sending you $15 00 in day or two. Uncle Frank dropped in and delivered my watch (or yours, rather).
Cost $3 00 for repairs, much cheaper than could have done here. Keeps fine time now. Is yours back yet? Forgot to ask him about it. More news in a day or two.

 Much love   K.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                      Oct. 21, 1921.

Dearest Mummie:

 The box of Marvin's outfit just arrived and is very lovely. Thank you ever so much. It is ever so pretty and dainty. The embroidery is such an addition to it, and

I know that it will look fine on him.  When he is all dressed up, will take his picture so you can see. I bought a baby bunting for him to wear in severe weather,
so now he is all fixed.

 Malcolm has a crowd of young men friends here crawling over the floor with various articles from the play cupboard. Have just warned them they must pick

everything up before they go, but they seemed not to hear. May have some trouble enforcing the law a little later.

 I bragged too soon about my hair. It was no sooner in than it was out, so to speak, and I am back where I started from. Still have enough to look all right

but not the abundance I did have - and it is still coming out. Hope will not be bald.

 Helen Frank still with Mrs. Sturges at Hillside & Mt. Clair. Does not seem
Completed

entirely contented. Met her husband some days ago when he came out to meet her here, and he says she is discontented everywhere.

 Nellie Zay is going south for the winter. Expects to locate with her mother's sister in Lakeland.    Papa left for Alabama on the 15th. Am having Ed and his

wife here for dinner tomorrow evening. Afterwards going to the O.F. dance at the Turner Hall, if the Powers are willing. It will be my first dance in about a year.

 Malcolm started kindergarten at Mrs. Wagoner's (the postmaster's mother and sister) the 1st of the month. Did I tell you? Is learning lots of nice things. Makes

mats by weaving paper, does paper cutting to make designs, has learned a number of rhymes, songs, etc. $5 00 per month.

 The XV I was to enclose has dwindled to X as Max is taking out a little life insurance and has to pay the premium this week. Will send another X next week. Have

a million things to do all the time. Hope will get caught up sometime. Do you remember my verse "In Florida"? Have given it to our esteemed Glen Ellyn and will
probably appear this week. They printed a perfectly dreadful poem last week so I decided they could use mine.     Much love   Katharine.
on sides:
Am forwarding a seed catalog mailed to G.M. here. Meant to get it off before. Potted the plants yesterday. Have 3 geranium and amaryllis with amaryllis
bulbs in another pot.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                    Oct. 29, 1921.

Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 X enclosed. Rainy today. Temperature 60 degrees. Not any hard frost so far. Have to keep a small fire in the furnace most of the time.
 am enclosing a couple of things Malcolm made at kindergarten. Have I mentioned his going before? He started 1st of the month at Mrs. Wagner's and likes it - 

all but the idea of having to go and having to do as the teacher says. He does not like to feel that he must do anything. He likes to think things over and then do his way.
Fortunately, his way is generally the right way, and if not he is easy to reason with, but it takes time and patience.

 One morning he said he was not going to go to kindergarten and said it very firmly. Didn't like it and would not go. Tried to find out what there was about it he didn't

like. "Well, didn't like to do everything the teacher tells me."   Well, I thought, if I let him stop, he will
Completed

bring up the same objection when he has started to school, and then it will be harder to combat.

 So, I thought very hard, while he began to feel rebellious and displayed his feelings by tearing small bits off a card of clasp fasteners on the table. "If you make me go

to K. I will tear up this card" etc.    Then I made a speech similar to the following. "Now, Malcolm, I want you to understand just why it is that I want you to go to K.
You know, when you get to be a big man, you won't be here with us all the time, as you are now. You will have to go to work and earn your living as other folks do.
But you can't do that unless you are educated and when we say educated we mean that you have to be trained - taught to use your mind to think with and your hands
to work with. And kindergarten is the first step in  education - and then comes grammar school, high school and college. You will be going to all those and if you go to
kindergarten you will find grammar school much easier, and will enjoy the work more than if you did not go. and if you go to K. you will be well trained and well trained
people can make more money
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.

and can enjoy life more than people who are not well trained. # and then you will be able to have a nice home of your own, and buy things for yourself and your children to make them comfortable."

 He gradually stopped tearing the card and when I finished, he said "All right, Mama, I will go to kindergarten. I didn't want to go before because I didn't understand.

But now I do, and I'm sorry I tore the card." (at which I felt much gratified.)

 Our kitten has just caught its 4th mouse, and is playing with it under my chair.
  Papa mailed us a box of cumquats and small oranges about half as big as tangerines. Do not know - crossed out  In his letter he calls them satsuma oranges.

Says will be back in about two months and will visit us on Christmas Day if convenient.    Would like very much to have mittens to match the sweater if you have time
Completed

to make them. Have not got around to fix the ribbons yet, but expect to do so some time next week. Am anxious to write scenario for the Daily News contest, which
closes Nov. 1st; you see I haven't much time left.

 Got a letter yesterday from Mrs. Marshall which mentions some snapshots that she is sending me - I judge they are some that you have given her, and she says that

no one will care for them as she does, when she has passed on, and I and my children will be glad of them.

 Sold old John yesterday. Took five men 3 hours to get him fixed up and out of the yard. Then he refused to go farther than the school house and had to be towed

to Wheaton. Max was at work, or he could have driven him without any trouble. The 2nd gear is worn out. Do not expect to get another one until the winter is nearly
over, as have no place to keep it. May get a runabout then I could take it out alone.

 Malcolm hungry. Must stop and get lunch. Marvin 16 1/2 lbs. last Sunday - naked weight.       Much love,   Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Nov. 7, 1921.

Dearest Mum:

 Enclosed find V.
 Am breaking away from home this Wednesday from 12 to 6. Helen Frank will look after my family and administer a bottle feeding to Marvin in the middle

of the afternoon. I have ordered a pint bottle of baby milk from the milk man and will prepare the feeding before I go, so all she will have to do is heat it up.

 Laura, Norine and I are going to a matinee. Do not know yet what we will see. Laura will get the tickets. Then I will take Max's train home.

Am going in on the 12:07
Completed

which arrives at 12:45 and is the fastest train on the time card. Makes no stops between here and Kedzie Avenue.

 Marvin weighed 16 3/4 lbs. on the 5th which is 1/4 lb. more than Malcolm weighed at the same age.
 Am enclosing some pictures you may be interested in.  Among the houses of the nobility you will see castle Ashby. Did Lady

Johnson secure the pictures of it and Compton Wingates that hung in the front room?

 I never have heard from Pattie since that letter nearly a year ago. I suppose she will write sometime. Her life with its ups and

downs would make a good movie serial.

 Helen Frank is staying
Completed

at Mrs. Higgins' (the chicken farm place near Hillside on Mt Clair, where we used to get eggs occasionally.

 Have received bad news of Nellie Zay who was hit by a street car while stopping at Columbus, Ga. and is now at a hotel there with an

injured shoulder. Expects to be laid up about 8 weeks. They were to take an X-ray of it. Have not heard the result yet.

 I sunned your dress the other day preparatory to mailing it. The goods you spoke of is in the dresser drawer and will send with the dress.
 The dress looks so well as it is would be too bad to go to trouble of
Completed

altering. Why not try one of the Warner corselettes. Cut enclosed. They must be very comfortable and not
binding in any way.  I expect to get one when I have worn out my corsets.

 Must stop & bathe baby.     Much love      Katharine

P.S.  Just got letter from N.Z.  X-ray showed 7 ribs and collar bone broken.  Feeling better.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Nov. 16, 1921.

Dearest Mum:

 Saw "Nice People" at the Cort last Wednesday with Laura & Norine. Guess I told you was planning to go. Had a quick lunch at the N.W. depot lunchroom first then walked over. Play not so good as some I have seen, but enjoyed the outing very much. L & N are coming out Sunday for dinner.
 Malcolm has been attending Sunday School at the Episcopal Church more or less regularly (Mrs. Hiatt is his teacher) and thereby is the means of helping his pa and

ma break into society. I was asked to donate some candy to the church Bazaar (which is being held today and tomorrow in the Guild Hall) and the family has also a
special invitation to attend a Sunday School party next Saturday evening. Moreover, we are going to the church dinner and entertainment and dance this evening, are
taking Malcolm and the baby to the dinner, then will bring them home and
Completed

return to the festivities later. Dorothy Bolms, a very nice little girl, about 15 years old, is coming to look after them.

 Malcolm's kindergarten is located in the old grey house the Le Stages used to live in, on Main street, so he does not have to cross the tracks.
  Have discovered some very delightful books by Galsworthy in the library. Have read "Beyond" and "In Chancery" and am reading "To Let", sequel to "In Chancery".

These last are especially good. Have you read them. May send them to you for Christmas unless there is something you would rather have.

 Have inquired about Mrs. Marsh's notice. Miss Boyle, the chief director, who was not in when I first left the notice, says that it is not possible to post any notices

except those of interest to the entire community, such as announcements of meetings to be held, etc. and she suggests that if Mrs. Marsh wants to get in touch with a
bookish person, she might send an ad to the Public Library Bulletin or whatever their official paper is called. I should think, though, that an ad in The Tribune would bring big results, or even one in the Glen Ellyan. Shall I put one in? Am mailing you some magazines that contain very good story by Edna Ferber which I think you will enjoy. As
after thought tried to thrust copy of Glen Ellyan into center
Completed

of the roll, but with indifferent success. Believe the poem will be intact, however.

 Have bought a barrel of apples for $7.00 and 2 bu. bag of potatoes for $3.15.   Malcolm said something funny at supper the other evening.

"My nose smells my cake. It makes me vicious."( Much gnashing of teeth.)

 Got my scenario into the contest all right. Wish I could win the $10,000, or even $500, would not be sneezed at.
  Must stop and wash diders, dishes, sweep, make beds, clean bathroom, mend, get lunch, etc.
 Much love,    Katharine

V or X later.
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                      Nov. 25, 1921.

Dear Folks:

 Enclosed find X.   
 Had nice visit with Laura and Norine Sunday. Served chicken, mashed potato, peas, hot rolls, creampie with whipped cream atop, and coffee.

Would have had salad but had forgotten to buy lettuce. However, there was plenty of chicken (Oscar sent 2 small ones (total $2 00) so nobody went hungry.

 Am going in town to the theater with them next Monday evening. Do not know yet what we shall see. Max will take care of the children. Am playing at the

show tonight, and played for yesterday's matinee. No company yesterday. Roast beef for dinner. Baked it too long. Very dried out. Had pumpkin pie from the p. given
us by the Wests some time ago.

 Weighed Marvin this morning. 17¼ lbs. not bad. He wore his new sweater and bonnet to the bazaar, and did look to
Completed

sweet for anything. Have taken his picture in the bunting and will get some of him in the sweater outfit on the remainder of the film.

 Mrs. Kopp entertained 28 young folks at Virginia's party on armistice Day in the evening. She says she hasn't got over it yet. Brought us some "cold party"

the next morning. Lot of cake of various kinds and some small candies in baskets. We donated our phonograph. Virginia is having her teeth straightened. Goes
to town every Saturday.

 Am trying to make Malcolm some blouses. Guess I told you I got the stuff some time ago. Could do a lot of sewing if had more time. He needs some new mittens

and there is enough of that red yarn left to make some. Would either of you have time to knit some if I send the yarn with a drawing of his hand? Can easily buy
some if you will not have time.

 Do not hear from Helen. Had better write and tell her our car is sold. Probably thinks it strange we don't drive over. The time I mentioned the car being sold, I didn't

make it clear that the 5 men had come of their own accord to assist the new owner (one of them) in putting on tires etc. Sold for $35 00. Gears worn out.

 Much love,   Katharine
Completed

M.M. Moore  Art Department                                                                      K.K. Moore  Business Mgr.

                                        M. M. MOORE
                                         Photo Pillow Tops
                                                                                                   Glen Ellyn, ILL.
                                                                                                     Dec. 5, 1921.

Dear Mum:

 Have mixed up the bread and got the first washerful of clothes in - 5 minutes past ten. Was up at 6:30, as usual, got Max's breakfast, then dressed myself after nursing 

Marvin, set him on the jar "a spell", got Malcolm out and dressed, breakfasted and off to kindergarten. That is the usual morning routine and it is generally 10 o'clock
before I begin to accomplish anything. The little, seemingly unimportant things take up so much time.

 Saw Tip-Top at the Colonial (with Fred Stone) that is, he is in the cast - was accompanied by Laura and Norine, last Monday evening. Very fine, and such an ideal play

for children that I persuaded Max to take Malcolm to the Saturday matinee and they both enjoyed it very much. It will be pleasant for Malcolm to look back upon, I think,
as his first visit to the
Completed

theater. It was a musical show with pussycats, Indians, fancy dancing, and plenty of fun.

 Cousin Martha, Sam and Mrs. Western took dinner with us a week ago Saturday. Martha is a nice looking little girl, and can toddle around and talk a bit. will be

two years old the last day of March.

 Am enclosing X or 2 V's, rather. Glad you liked "The Girls". The book critic in The News fussed considerably at the ending, being displeased that Edna Ferber

saddled Lottie with a war baby but to me, the ending was the best part. It seemed so natural that after the repression that Lottie had endured in her earlier years, 
she should finally burst her bonds and go to the limit, so to speak.

 Am reading Main Street from the library. Very good so far. Have you read it?
 Baby awake so must stop. 6 months old today. 17½  lbs. yesterday.                  Much love,   Katharine.

Malcolm 18¼ at 6 months.
Completed

Dec. 19, 1921.

 Dear Folks:
 Had already ordered sweater when your letter arriving, specifying a black one. Had ordered lavender and as the shade is a very good one, am sending it along in

hopes Grandma will like it. It would look very well with her nice white hair.

 Frank wrote me regarding sweater and is paying $3 00 on same. He said he had got you a handbag, Mum, so I will have to think up something else. If it does not

reach you by Christmas, it will soon afterward. I cannot take the baby with me while the stores are so crowded and may not be able to get anyone to
Completed

look after him this week.

 Shall be very glad indeed to have the oranges. Hope the mitten yarn arrived safely. Marvin's mittens are lovely and a very good fit. Enclosed find photos of Marvin; 

also V.

 Am going to try taking a picture of him in the house so he wont have to be bundled up. In one of the pictures he has on sweater, bonnet and mittens.
  Just waking up so must stop. Wish you both were spending Christmas with us. Hope you will have pleasant day and be well remembered.
     Much love   Katharine.
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Dec. 26, 1921.

Dear Folks:

 The fruit came on the 23rd and is very fine.  Many, many thanks. We have some at every meal and are enjoying it much.
 The red mittens and your letter with enclosures came yesterday. Mittens are a very good fit. Thank you very much.
   Papa was out yesterday. We had a nice visit. He gave us $20 00 this year to buy each of us presents. Quite nice, don't you think?

I bought string of pearl beads with my share, got Marvin
Completed

2 new shirts, rubber boots for Malcolm and Hub a razor strop. Still some left.

 Marvin had a fever the other night and has had a cold and cough. All right again. Discovered two teeth through yesterday morning which probably accounts

for at least half of his trouble. Probably caught his cold from Malcolm, who brought his home from kindergarten.  We are going to have dinner at the Gray's
today. He is now editor of the Glen Ellyn. Due now so must stop.   V enclosed.

  Much love   Katharine.
Completed

X Enc.                        Glen Ellyn, ILL.

                                   Jan. 6, 1922.

Dear Mum:

 So sorry to hear of Mrs. Huston's death. I know it has grieved you very much. I wrote at once to Miss Rhinesmith and to Roger. Have asked R. out to dinner

this Sunday. Have explained to Miss R. about the delay in forwarding the letter. I set it aside to forward and it got buried under some papers. Thought it was
just a Christmas card. Hope Roger will get damages from the company.

 Papa was out Christmas. Guess I told you.    My best gift was one to myself of a vacuum cleaner - Eureka - . A wonderful help. Takes a pound of dirt per day

out of the house. Cleans register boxes and
Completed

everything - tops of books - tops of door casings - pillows clothes, etc. I have all the attachments. $5 00 per month. Total cost $48 50.

 This was my washday so haven't time to write much. Will try to answer your several letters on Sunday. Have enjoyed them all very much. Will

try to get in to town some day next week and see if can find card case.

 Glad of any hints regarding keeping children well. Still nursing Marvin altogether. Every 4 hours now. Has only had 2 bottle feedings in his life,

and those not recently.

 Sits up alone now. Weighs 18¼  lbs.  7 months old.  Margaret's baby 1 year on the 12th.  What would Grandma like for birthday.
         Love    Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

 Jan. 13, 1922.

Dearest Mum:

 Your letter and one from Helen in same mail. will enclose it as you were asking about her. Need not return. I had not heard from her nor seen her for several months

so wrote her several days ago, this being her reply. I'm glad she has kept her humorous style of writing. It is so refreshing.

 I am planning to have a birthday party for Malcolm and must go to town some day next week to see about paper napkins and invitations and other customaary

embellishments. Perhaps I can find your card case at the same
Completed

time.

 Max fixed up the old typewriter some weeks ago and Malcolm is making use of it. spells "cat" and "dog" and "hot" and "wet" and "cow" and has incidentally

used up all the "M M Moore" stationery. Got Malcolm a new overcoat yesterday ordered by mail from Mandel's. Cost $10 95 and looks like  Mich. ?Boul.?.
has fur collar and quilted lining. Mixed brown goods something like my coat. Will take his picture in it and send it to you. Did I send you picture of Marvin in
his bunting and sweater. Took 2 in his bathtub not yet developed.

 Am sending grandma Woman's Home Companion
Completed

and wish her many happy returns of the day. Her birthday is tomorrow.

 Margaret's Betty has been sick. Went up to see her Wednesday for a few minutes and took her a bathrobe for birthday present. They have a comfortable house, 

quite modern, the kind with large living room, small dining, and kitchen.

 Marvin on porch napping. Temp. 18º at present, 2:30 p.m.
 Roger did not come Sunday. Got letter later saying had previous engagement. Washed yesterday afternoon. Visited the kindergarten in the morning.  Expect to invite 11 kids
Completed

to party, making a dozen in all. Want Laura and Norine to come too if they can. They are both so fond of children and would like to help entertain.

 Made Malcolm nice pair of trousers out of my black and white checked skirt and have enough goods for another pair, or perhaps a light weight coat for spring.
 Furnace doing very well this winter. Fire keeps nicely over night. Burn Illinois Lump, $10 00 per ton.

Get a peck of dirt out of v.c. every time, I empty dust bag. Don't know where it all comes from, but quite a satisfaction to burn it.

 Another new house going up in the meadow, just back of Morse's and little to east.      Love,  Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

Jan. 19, 1922.

Dearest Mum:

 Enclosed find X. Please let me know how far behind I am. Have been rather remiss lately in keeping accounts. Will make up defecit as soon as I can. Must pay

coal bill this week.

 Do you remember whether there is a copy of The Folly of Being Good here? Seems to me I saw a quantity of pamphlets with that thin red paper binding a long

time ago, but have not been able to find them. Papa wants the above, as intends to revise it, and has no copy of his own.
Completed

Got the enclosed yesterday from Pattie; almost exactly one year from the time I received the other mysterious epistle from Detroit. Wonder if my letter in reply will

be returned as the other was? She always has lots of news to tell, but never tells it. Perhaps will have better luck this time.

 Believe I entirely forgot to mention a very important occurrence on Christmas Day when Marvin displayed 2 teeth! They look very businesslike by this time and think

he will soon have 2 more to go with them.

 We all went to town
Completed

last Sunday on the 10 o'clock train after an early dinner and attended the concert at the Art Institute. It is the first I have heard for a number of years. it was very
good and they played at least 2 numbers that I remember having heard at other of their concerts. Afterwards in the lobby, I saw Mr. Blake, and accosted him.
He didn't know me until I told him I was May Walden's daughter. He admired the baby and said he would write and tell you he had met me. He was looking 
very well.

 Marvin was exceedingly well behaved during the
Completed

concert. He sat erect and dignified on his father's knee and was a model of conduct. did not so much as crow or gurgle to annoy the musicians. This was
his first public performance of any kind.

 I am planning to go to town tomorrow with Malcolm to do some birthday shopping and get his hair cut "short like a boy". He is a little too big to look well with

it bobbed.    I wonder how he will look. Will send you a picture of him..14 degrees at present. Only 10 degrees a little while ago.  Got H.G. Wells' "Joan and Peter" 
from library. His style something like Galsworthy's, I think.  Did I tell you Austin Flett is out of work?

    Much love,  Katharine
Completed

P.S.  Just found your letter in box.  Yes, it is a Eureka cleaner - Detroit, Mich. is where they are manufactured.   Marvin creeps backwards a little, especially when
on a bed, will soon let himself over the edge feet first, if not watched.   Has not had a fall yet. Malcolm had had several at this age, but he had no brother to help
watch him. He likes to play with his little balls. If I give him the box containing them, he takes it in one hand and swings it out over the edge of the buggy, until the
Completed

balls fall out onto the floor. Then he plays with the box.

 Am just making a blouse for Malcolm. will send you the pattern in a few days. The collar in the pattern is too large. will either trim it off or substitute another.
     Much love      K.
Completed

[February, 1922]

  Friday,  8 p.m.

Dearest Mummie:

 Blouses arrived in due time on the birthday and are ever so nice. Thank you very much. They will be most useful as Malcolm needs a fresh one every day and

I had only 4 that were decent, so had to wash them out sometimes between washdays. will not have to now, as Mrs. Feist gave him one also (Buddy's present at the party)
and I am making hin one (have been at it off and on for a couple of weeks, so that will make 8.
Completed

Must tell you about the party. Got at my baking at 10:30 on Tuesday. By 1 o'clock had made 3 layer chocolate birthday cake, cream pie, 1 loaf cake, and an apple pie.
Frosted the extra cake and made the filling for the cream pie on Wednesday. Laura and Norine had said they would come, so felt sure everything would turn out all right
and did not worry. Only 3 people acknowledged the invitations I sent out, but called up a couple
Completed

of mothers, and learned through Malcolm's having talked to the children, that the others were coming. One boy was sick and couldn't come (got a note while the party 
was in progress) and Annette Gray's mother forgot about it, so she couldn't come. Her mother has to look after the newspaper office most of the time, has 3 small
children and is expecting another, so do not wonder at her not being able to remember it.

 The others all came and there were 9 guests, making 10 at the table, all
Completed

children, as Norine, Laura and I served. Had minced ham sandwiches, a portion of cream pie each with whipped cream and marchino cherry atop, cake with
frosting, chocolate cake, ice cream and little candies in baskets. Had snaps or "pulls" whatever you call them with favors inside, and pretty little heart shaped
baskets, and a bouquet of sweetpeas on the table. Got along without borrowing any dishes, silverware or chairs. Would
Completed

not have been able to manage if N. and L. had not come. Got lunch for them at a little after 1 o'clock and had to hustle for the 2:30 guests.

 The girls were splendid help. I had them use the cleaner and dust while I got lunch. Then Norine entertained the children all the time they were here

while Laura helped me with the table and making sandwiches and serving. Besides the children, we served 3 grownups who came at
Completed

4:30 to call for them. Never realized before what slim appetites children have. Nearly everyone left fully half of their cream pie. Hardly any ate the extra cake,
although pieces were small, and quite a bit of birthday cake was left on the plates. Another time I will omit the cream pie. I don't mind the work but hate to
have it wasted. They all brought presents. Malcolm got a windsor tie, several games, a ball, a tinker
Completed

toy set, 3 boxes of candy, some handkerchiefs, and picture books.  Max got him new shoes, and a blue serge suit.

 The baby enjoyed it all immensely. The children all had a good time, apparently, and Malcolm said he wished he could have a party every day. Tomorrow is washday

and Sunday Papa is coming out.

 Laura and Norine were so nice. They did everything very efficiently and were so helpful.   I had them stay over
Completed

night, and we had a pleasant evening playing cards. They left at about 2:30 the next afternoon. We are planning to see a show together the evening of the 24th,
which is Laura's next day off. Laura brought me a lovely little white romper suit for Marvin which she had made and embroidered. This is the third she has given
him.

 Tonight I sent Malcolm over to Mrs. Maurer's to return a can opener I had borrowed the other day when mine broke.
Completed

When he came back I said, "Did you see Mrs. Maurer?"   "No" he replied.  "A man came to the door - fully grown."

 Tonight at bedtime he wanted me to admire a man he had drawn on the blackboard, embellished with orange and green eyes. he remarked, "Its very colorish".

I wish I could remember all the unusual things he says. Here is a verse he has composed    "Mr Bim all white and stern with a villain on his yearn"
Completed

I enclose one of the invitations for you to see and keep. I have another for the diary. Aren't they pretty? Jack Thomas sent M. a card.

 Letter from Pattie enclosed. Need not return. Glad to have news at last. Should like to see her.
 Austin has a job now with Procter and Gamble. Goes to Milwaukee; home every week-end. Margaret told me in a phone conversation yesterday that

she now weighs 184 lbs. Says she is trying to diet but it is hard work. Betty is better.

 Will send some new pictures soon.   X enclosed.    Has G.M. received Womans'
Completed

Home Companion yet?  Mine has not come, so have written the company to look up order.

  Much love to both    Katharine.

P.S. Your poem to Malcolm is too lovely. It is the sweetest thing you ever wrote and I am going to preserve it in the diary.

Many thanks, Mother dearie.
Completed

Dear Mum:

 Am hurrying over town with Marvin while sun is shining (was raining this a.m.).
  Want to get X off to you. Will answer your letter later. Enjoyed it very much.
Temp 48º just now. Warmest for a long time.     Tax statements rec'd couple of days ago.

Yours enclosed. Opened it as it was addressed to Mary W. Kerr a lady unknown in Avon Park.

  Love,   K.
Completed

2-24-22   On N.W. train en route to city.
               Friday 5:30 p.m.

Dear Mum:

 This is my evening off as you will observe by the heading and will pass the 1st part of it by trying to get some news off my chest.
  Renewed my acquaintance with some Laires and Penates of our family lately in this wise: - Got a letter postmarked

Elgin from Uncle Geo. saying that in looking over some of the contents of the barn which is soon to be torn down, he ran across a
box initialed M.W.K. which he thought contained garden tools. Which he would send me on receipt of shipping
Completed

instruction. I replied 2 express collect so in a few days it arrived. The family hammer was temporarily missing so Malcolm, nothing daunted, opened it with 2 screw drivers
one pillow came to light - also one comforter - patch work on one side and red material of some sort on the other. The filling seems to be a white or buff blanket, nice
and warm apparently and would be fine except that the patch work part is badly moth eaten. when it has been aired, will do very well.  Next came my little play table
Completed

the one that folded up.               3
It is in splendid condition and will be nice for the children. Mr. Ingram's old spade, and also the little rake and spade which belonged to him came next. They are
all right. During the unpacking I came upon an occasional piece of wood and wondered what these were from. At the bottom I found out. The pail of the old
ice cream freezer had separated into its original sections and lay there, pathetically. The metal top and handle were there too. Then at the bottom
Completed

I found an old pail      4
made of earthenware, and I judge from the label (5 lbs. hazel butter) that you got it years ago from Siegel? Coopers. In it I found a pair of old black mittens
badly motheaten. Then there were 2 bread knives, one rusty, the other not so rusty, also the little bicycle seat in which I used to ride on papa's bike. Also a sickle, 
and some hose attached to a pump spray outfit. Max says latter will be OK. after new washer has been put in; wrapped separately was a map
Completed

and a terribly big businesslike broom!         5

Well, I am on my way to meet Laura and Norine. We are going to have dinner together and then go to the new apollo Theater. I have never been there before

and they say it is very beautiful. They just have vaudeville there now, but have not seem a v. show for a long time so am looking forward to it.

 Grandpa Faier Laier? died a few days ago. His funeral was yesterday. He could not have been sick very long as I had seen him out walking not long ago. He always seemed well and cheerful. Have not heard what the
Completed

matter was.                                  6

 About two weeks ago two babies died. One was the baby Mrs. Maurer was raising (her granddaughter) the other was Frances Crisler's niece, her sister's baby.

It had erysipilas (spelled wrong) can't stop train to look it up) baby was 3 months old. The other baby (both girls) was 2 weeks older than Marvin. she had no teeth -
seemed to have trouble cutting them, was jaundiced at birth. Seemed well - quite plump - was given rye bread to chew on. Also had tea. Fear improper feeding
helped to cause death, though
Completed

Mrs. M's doctor told her       7
after it was over he did not think she could ever have raised her. She had a convulsion one day and died the next. Dr. Schiele was called but not soon enough.
He treated her one day, but think he should have been called a week or two weeks before hand, though Mrs. M. didn't consider her trouble serious. Would a
chunk of rye bread cause a convulsion?   Marvin is fine. Has 4 teeth now. He is with Max tonight who came home early to be there when I left.
Completed

Max left Type Founders a week ago.          8
He was getting $40 00 per week when he left, but the board of directors declared a 20 percent wage cut to affect everyone
including the head ones, so he and 4 others left. He started right in with another firm and is getting $35 00 to start. They are in the automobile accessory business, 
supplying dealers. They have a printing shop at Kedzie Ave. where Hub is at present. This is all the paper I brought so must stop.

  Much love     Katharine
Completed

[3-6-22]
X enc.           On train again  Monday
Dear Mum:

 Am going to City on 12:07 to get new tires on a couple of buggy wheels. Left the children with Mrs. Kopp. Am paying her, so my mind is at rest.

Do not like to take up her time without remuneration. This is a fine train No stops between G. E. & Kedzie Ave.  Meant to ack. blouses in
my last letter
Completed

but forgot. They are all lovely and I thank you very much. Malcolm is certainly well stocked now. Saw a nice romper pattern that would do for Marvin in the
1 year size, in the companion for March. Will have one sent to you. Shall I send goods for them?  Your village seems to have a lot of social life. Rivals Chicago
even and far surpasses G.E.
Completed

We went over to the McKoys Sat. eve. and played 500 with them & the Kopp's. Their baby, Donald is nearly 18 months old now, very bright, not pretty, but
healthy and very active. Talks a little. She weaned him at 9 months, gradually being completely weaned at 12 months. Not feeling well last night. Another sick
headache
Completed

Have had 5 or 6 lately, about 3 weeks apart. Baby seemed feverish, so to assure ourselves sent for Dr, Schiele. We all have colds, Malcolm brings them
home from the Feist's. Dr. said baby had fever 102 but didn't seem so to me. He sat up and played with the Dr.  stethoscope and seemed very
lively, as he always does. I'm sure he
Completed

had no fever an hour after the Dr. left. He left some black pills for the baby which I put in the furnace  He said the baby was doing so well on my milk that I
ought not to begin weaning before 11 months. He asked me if there were headaches in the family. I told him Papa used to have headaches but
Completed

but I didn't know whether they were sick headaches or not. Were they? It says in your N. lectures that migrain may be inherited. Am going to try to get
outdoors more and take an int. bath once a week.   Thank you,  Grandma, for Malcolm's dollar. Will try to get some sewing and outfits with it. He likes to
sew. Has learned how to sew buttons on his underwear.         Much love     Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.
March 19, 22.
Dear Mum:

 Many thanks for nice white blouse and Tinker Tom.  The Westerns sent the baby one at Christmas, but we are glad to have another, as the baby finds

it a very attractive toy.  So does Malcolm. He said he would take the old one for his now, and let the baby have the new one.

 Malcolm has been quite well so far as stomach is concerned. He eats lots of fruit and seldom anything between meals except an occasional
Completed

2
apple. I have been buying apples by the box all winter, so that we always have fruit in the house.

 No, I'm not pregnant. My hair is coming in now quite thick again and stopped coming out about six weeks ago. Last Sunday I felt pretty miserable.

Vomited again. It was some tomato soup I had eaten the previous Friday and Saturday evening. Am going to swear off canned tomatoes altogether.
Believe I may have inherited Papa's antipathy for them.
Completed

3
Felt as though I must do something for my stomach so have been eating somewhat on the order of Dr. Boffenmeyer's ideas this week, and have felt better.
Have taken 4 oranges and a qt. or nearly a qt. of milk for breakfast. Then toast and eggs at noon. Then meat and a huge place of lettuce  celery and apples
for supper. No bread for supper. No bread that is not toasted at any meal. No potato this week. No starch with the meat and
Completed

4       
no starch with the fruit. Nellie Zay is sending Physical Culture in Malcolm's name and found a helpful article on diet in it giving a classification of foods into
acids, starches and neutrals. This is helpful in planning menus for myself. I weigh 123 lbs. My color is good and I feel well most of the time. Last word from
N.Z. was card saying she was going to Biggs Sanitarium in Asheville, N.C.

 Am mailing pattern for Malcolm's trousers
Completed

5   
also a number of odds and ends that have turned up that you may be able to use. am including a romper pattern that I got here in town.

 Marvin is now wearing the short outfit (petticoats and dresses that you and Grandma made for Malcolm. The little tatted dress is in good shape

still and looks so nice on him.

 He did lots of creeping today. Goes both frontwards and backwards now.    Yes, Malcolm speaks excellent English. His vocabulary is very large.
Completed

6
I started out once to make a list of unusual words that he is able to use but there are so many of them that I did not make very rapid progress.

 About social vices, a new neighbor, Richard Chase, 5 years old, is very bad that way and I have been obliged to forbid him the house. M. is all

right when kept busy, and when playing with children who do not take the initiative in the matter.

 Shall be glad to have a box of the g.f. but hate to put you to the
Completed

7
trouble of packing it. Have priced it here can't get anything for less that [sic] $5 00 per case out here. Quoted at 4.00 to 4.50 wholesale. Express is $3 00.

 Am giving the baby a small sliver of toast crust every morning at breakfast. Sometimes  chokes on it so have to watch him. Usually spits it all out on his

bib but seems to enjoy chewing on it. Have given him a little beef broth occasionally, but not
Completed

8
regularly. Shall be glad to have fever thermometer. Your number is 21969. Let me know how much it is and I will remit. I have not forgotten that your Christmas
present is still unsent. Hope to get it to you before your birthday arrives.

 If I cannot get the card case, how would you like silk petticoat, or bloomers? Let me know what length , if petticoat.
 Attended a bunco party given my [sic] Eva Mertz, now Mrs. Burgess, at the old Mertz farm on Hill Ave. last week. She has 2 little girls both with red hair like hers

X enc.       Love,  Katharine
Completed

Monday, 11 a.m.

 4-3-22.

Dear Folks:

 Had a big snowstorm on the 31st, but most of it melted the next day.  50º this morning.
 Looks like rain, so must make this brief, as want to run over town before noon.
 Had lots of company yesterday.  Some business friends of Max's whom I had not met before. Messrs. Gilson & Shawyer 

and their wives and the Shawyer baby, a boy, 1 month older than Marvin. Very pleasant people. Enjoyed their visit.  Served g. fruit
with m. cherry - boiled chicken
Completed

and gravy, radishes  green onions, mashed potatoes, spinach with h.b. egg, banana salad, cream pie with w. cream, and coffee. Did
the whole business myself without assistance and managed to clean house previously and keep it clean till company arrived.

 Malcolm's trousers should measure 15 inches from waist band to knee and waist measure is 25 inches.
  X enclosed.  Am planning to have Papa out on his 62nd birthday. May bake b. cake but think I shall omit the candles.
    Much love     Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, ILL.

April 13, 1922.

Dearest Mum:

 It is about time I was acknowledging the fruit, before it is all eaten. Arrived very promptly a day before the letter in which you said you were sending it.

All was in fine shape and lovely fruit. Much sweeter and juicier than the store fruit.

 Had Frances Crisler over to take lunch with me the day it arrived and served some then.
  Yes, Papa's taste in wearing apparel has not varied over the years.
Completed

I suppose he needs quite a sum for carfare between Chicago and Fairhope.

 N.Z. is still in feeble health. Her Aunt Nell is with her (her mother's sister. she was in Asheville for a month or so and a card today gives her

address as Springfield, Tenn.

 Fever thermo. came promptly. Used it last night on Marvin, but temp. was normal. Had a touch of croup. Nose running some today. Malcolm

coughing some. Picked up a cold somewhere in the neighborhood.     Am weaning Marvin.

 Started last week.
Completed

Has been having one cup of diluted milk each day at 1 o'clock. Takes it rather well. Seldom drinks more than 2/3 of it.

 Did I mention the death of Grandpa Laier some time ago? No, Mrs. Saunders is very much alive and looks 10 years younger since her

bereavement. It must have been a happy release. Geo. S. accosted me on the street yesterday with reference to the diary and asked
me to look up the various memoranda that may have to do with her marriage.   I think she deserves all she can get out of it. Geo.  can
make a tidy
Completed

living at his trade so believe I shall not be able to find anything.

 Must take Malcolm to dentist at 4 and it is time to get ready.
  Our neighbors, the Wests, moved in about 2 weeks ago. Haven't had time to call yet. Don't do calling, as a rule, 

but she has been very nice to me, and wish to be courteous, at least.

 Marvin fussing. Must stop.
 Enclosing 2 00 for the thermo.
    Much love  -  Katharine.
Completed

X Enc.                   April 19, 1922.

 Dear Mum:
  We have been having a very worried time with Marvin - still are, for that matter  He was noticeably ill Friday evening. Called Dr. Potter, who said it

was a cold and teething, with perhaps some indigestion. The fever thermometer has been in almost constant use ever since. What is the normal
temperature for a baby when teething?

 I have taken his every hour and when
Completed

it got high, 104 1/10, every half hour. Got up to that mark Friday evening and Saturday evening. Then would gradually go down to as low as 99 1/2. Has
not been lower and a few hours ago had reached 103 1/5 again.   Yesterday seemed so much better didn't take temp. at all. he sat up in the buggy a
while and seemed quite normal, though weak, of course. He is sweating, just now.  and temperature is
Completed

lower. I think I will take it again when he wakes up. Like to let him rest all he can. His skin, or face, rather, is quite cool, even with a high fever so would
not know he had one if it were not for the thermometer.

 The doctor left some fever reducing medicine which I give him when temp. begins to climb.    Sat up with him until 2:30 a.m. both Friday and Saturday

evening. He seemed quite normal and had low
Completed

temp on Sunday. He coughs quite a bit and nose runs some.
Kept him off the breast for 36 hours, then began nursing every 4 hours.
My breasts had loads of milk Sunday and hardly a drop Monday. 
He doesn't get very much but like to have him suck at least every 4 hours to keep the milk from going away. 

There is lots of measles in town Am keeping Malcolm home from Kgn. He
Completed

has a cough but feels fine.
Don't know what to do regarding his eating,
This trouble all may be due to giving him toast and g. crackers, do you think so? Toast is recommended for that age in the gov. pamphlet. 
Have also given him a little chicken broth, beef broth and oatmeal gruel. Did not care for the latter He has had no sugar of any kind. 

Dr. Potter said he thought I was very wise not to give sugar as many mothers did.
Completed

But apparently I am not wise at all, or this would not have happened called Dr Oelke up once when could not get Dr. Potter. He advised me to give salt water injection,

a teaspoon of castoria and not to take the temp. any more. Then I wouldn't worry about it. Gave the injection, but baby had just had big bowel movement and temp.

had dropped 2 degrees immediately so injection was unnecessary. Gave castoria this morning. None previous.

 Marvin's two upper teeth
Completed

about 1/16 of an inch apart. Lower ones together. The 2 new ones are the uppers on each side of the ones already cut. Do you think they may be crowded and that would cause the fever? I am reading everything I can find on the subject, but don't find much about teething. He had a fever with his other teeth. Maybe it was high then, but did not know about it as had no thermometer.

I had begun to wean him and had been giving him a cup of modified milk once a day. Shall have to post
Completed

postpone that now and will nurse him all the time if my milk holds out. I suppose worrying has helped to decrease the supply. Have kept a record of temp. and other items since Friday.

 Do you think I had better nurse him all summer? I see Dr. Stockholm thinks weaning should be from 12 to 18 months. Malcolm never had a thing but breast milk at this age, and never was sick a minute. These modern doctors seem in a big hurry to get the babies weaned and to eating. Enclose clipping from Dr. Brody
Completed

Got a book from the library on the subject written about 10 years ago, which says that a baby should not have even cracker or toast until 14 or 15 months old
Marvin's bowels have been in fine shape all the time. never had a drop of medicine until this illness.

 Malcolm has just gone to dentist's. Had to send him alone, as could not leave or take the baby. Is it dangerous to take the baby out so long as he has any fever?

Hope he will be well by the time I hear from
Completed

you again.
It is cold today and windy. temp. 40 degrees. Has been warm several days and buds are well out. was interested in your reference to the lazy nest making mocker. 
Remembered in contrast the enterprising robin of last spring who built her nest in the ash tree. I think she got it done in two days, in spite of a high wind and rain
most of the time.

I fear this is a monotonous letter but I wanted to give you all the details.
    Much love -   Katharine

I keep a cloth on his throat wrung from hot water and covered with flannel.
Completed

4-21-22
Friday, 2 p.m.
Dear Mum:

 Yours just arrived. Believe I had better supplement my ill tidings of Wed. by saying that Marvin is quite normal now, and though a little weak, looks bright and cheerful, 

sleeps well and has good appetite. Believe the castoria effected the cure. Two hours after taking, had bowel movement, another later, and normal temperature
followed. I enclose history of case which you may peruse and return.
Completed

Was interested in Erma's letter, but can't understand how she could be in danger of starving when she has two boys old enough to work where is the Mr.?
  A new  family has moved into the Bentley house. They have a limousine and two little boys that look like twins from a distance - about 3 yrs. old.  Another

house is going up just east of the Bentley house.

 Hillside Avenue now is pretty thickly settled . The handsomest residence near us is the Dr. Somerville place, made of brick, s.w. corner of Hillside & Forest.
  Mar awake.  Must stop.     K.
Completed

5-4-22.
Thursday A.M.
Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 The lovely rompers and pants arrived Tuesday but carrier did not deliver them and when I called for the package Tues. evening, the office was closed so got

them yesterday.

 They are so pretty and fit perfectly, and so many of them! you don't know how rich I feel. And 2 pairs of trousers for Malcolm when I was expecting only one

pair! you are ever so good to me and
Completed

I appreciate it very much. The trousers fit fine and will be a great help with Malcolm's summer wardrobe. The blouses you sent him will do for the summer and
to start in school with next fall.

 Wish I could send you both something very nice, but as business is rather uncertain just now, shall have to wait, and merely enclose customary X.
  The first trees are all in blossom and look and smell beautifully. wish you could
Completed

see them.

 The Wests are putting their lot into good shape. They have tied a rope across the path which so many citizens have been wont to use, and are planting

rose bushes and grass seed, and perennials of various kinds. Mrs. West is much like Grandma in her love for flowers and her industry in setting them.

 I prepared a bit of virgin soil in the garden a few days ago and sowed some nasturtium seed. The soil was very hard and lumpy and
Completed

it took quite a while to get it in shape. Hope the plants will come up.  I am planning to dig up some of the lilies of the valley after they have bloomed and put out
pansy plants.  You had such a good bed there years ago.  I can get plants from the greenhouse at Taylor Avenue.

 I am enclosing some pictures of Marvin and Malcolm and the dog. Believe I have not mentioned him heretofore. Max brought him home from Chicago

several months ago  Found
Completed

him on Lake street in the loop, lost. Wore no collar and had apparently been lost some time. He got a collar, and muzzle and lead for him and the dog
rode out in state in the baggage car. He was glad to be adopted and is the best behaved dog we have had yet. Is clean around the house and never
steals anything from the tables. He guards the baby so well that none of the neighbors dare speak to him, much less touch him, when the
Completed

dog is in sight of the buggy. One day when we had not had him very long, Malcolm and the baby and I went to Lombard to attend a stork shower. The dog
followed us to the electric depot, where we left the buggy. We were gone 4 hours, and when we got back, there was the dog, sitting patiently by the buggy.

 He is very fond of Max and hates to see him go in the morning, but has learned not to follow him. We have been to the woods several mornings for a
Completed

walk. They have made a regular park on the west side of the lake.  Leveled the ground off, made a lawn, planted shrubs, pruned the trees, built a comfort
station such as they have in Chicago parks, and built a nice gravel walk which follows the lake shore around to the north end. It is smooth enough so one can
wheel a buggy comfortably. We have gathered quite a number of spring beauties, dog tooth violets, and anemones, but the blue
Completed

violets are not out yet - at least not where we have been.

 Mark Woods, the former constable, is in charge of the park improvement work, and has a number of young men helping him.
 They are excavating for the new high school building, which is to be built on honeysuckle hill. It is being built by the Lombard & Glen Ellyn

communities together and will be called the Glenbard school, which I think is zero in names. However, I guess it will be a nice building which is all
that matters.       Much love,  Katharine
Completed

5-26-22
Thursday Noon
Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 Have been putting off writing this, hoping to have some money to send you, but guess will have to send it later. Max's job has about petered out. It seems that

the people who own the printing shop he has been managing will have to give it up as their business is not doing well enough to keep it going and the
machinery bought on time, was only partly paid for.

 However, he was seeing some people this morn-
Completed

ing about a position as shop foreman (also printing) and if he gets this, all will be well. We have been living on our savings for the past two weeks as Max's job
was paying only partly what it should. Hope he can collect what they owe him. Fortunately for us, Mrs. Curtis has been called to California by the expected death
of Amos Churchill and I have been playing at the show. They give $2 00 a night now, so
Completed

4 nights and the Fri. Mat. bring a total of $9 00 which helps some. She expects to be gone 3 weeks.

 So glad you liked the flowers. Do you think lilies of the valley would grow if I should send some roots? I want to dig up some of them to make a pansy bed. 

Also, how can I pack them so they will keep fresh?    Never mind about the fruit. Can get plenty of rhubarb now & strawberries.  Marvin is the only member
of the family who really needs orange or g.f. juice. I am having
Completed

very good luck weaning him. He takes milk and oatmeal or pettijohn's* (strained) also zweiback and fruit juice. Agrees with him very well. I feed him from a cup.
I nurse him just twice a day now - at 10 at night and again at about 3 a.m. He then goes until 10 a.m. for his next meal.

 He and the dog are great pals. He climbs all over the dog and takes his head between his hands and says  ah-h h - very

* cereal
Completed

vociferously. He feeds the dog his toast quite often ad takes great pleasure in watching him eat it.  This morning Marvin and the dog had quite a tussle over
a paper bag on the kitchen floor. Each pulled hard, the dog growling and the baby "ah - ing" - the dog wagging his tail the while to show that there were no
hard feelings.

 Yes, he takes books out of the lower shelves. Has quite a pile now that he is playing with. He stands up in
Completed

his crib and jumps as Malcolm used to do.

 Mother your report was splendid. I think you may well feel proud of the fine work you have done for the community and I hope they appreciate it.
  Thank you for your nice letter, Grandma  I enjoyed it very much. The rompers are certainly fine, and I think of you every time I put one onto Marvin.
 Much love to both,    Katharine

June 10, 1922
Dear Mum & Grandmum:

 I am enclosing some pictures that Laura sent me - taken when she and Norine were out here. She says I may send these for you to keep and she will give

me another set.  All but one were taken down in the woods on the west side of the lake.

 Was much shocked this morning to find that our beautiful early cherry tree had blown over - must have happened last night while I was at the show. A heavy rain
Completed

and wind came up after a very hot day. The trees are both loaded with cherries and were sprayed early this spring so the fruit is in good condition.  I am going
to ship a bushel to you if I can get a proper container - something with a cover, such as cherries are marketed in.  The tree is broken off at about 2 feet above
the ground - trunk split wide open. It looks as though that place where it was fastened and bolted with wire may have been
Completed

a contributing cause of its going over. I felt very sad to see it - it is quite like losing one of the family.

 Max was expecting a check today so shall probably send you back rent on Monday.
  It has been quite warm past few days  Marvin is entirely weaned now. Has not nursed since the 5th.  It was not hard at all and he likes his new food very much.
 The cherries are ripe enough for pies now - some of them, anyway. The late tree is still green. Believe none
Completed

of the crop will be lost as a result of the accident, so long as we can get them picked.   I do not expect to can any, at most a dozen pints - as we have several
qt. jars on hand that are 2 years old.

 The red peonies are very pretty. Grown very tall. wish could send you some.
  Marvin slept out on the porch in his buggy last night, covered by mosquito tent.  Did not wake up till seven this morning.
     Much love   Katharine
Completed

June 14, 1922.
Dear Mum:

 I am favoring you with my first check in the amount of X$ which I hope to send each week until deficit is erased.
  1 bu. of cherries shipped yesterday which I hope will go through in good condition and will give you some good pies and sauce.

Several of the neighbors helped me pick. The basket is one that we had in the cellar and the cover for the basket I begged from
Mr. Janta, the wholesale vegetable man who sup-
Completed

plies all the local stores. The young man at the depot tied the twine around the cover to keep the expressmen enroute from eating the contents.

 Had Dr. Johnson over to pass his opinion on the cherry tree. He says to leave the stump as it is and some shoots will come out and make a new

tree that will bear just as the old one did.

 The inside of the trunk is badly rotted caused by some limbs being cut off many years ago, and not properly painted over. The other tree has props under one big limb
Completed

which will be amputated as soon as the crop is gathered - thus giving it a better balance.

 He says it is in the same condition inside as the one that fell over, but may last a good many years yet, it taken care of. The snow broke down the

propped limb of this one last winter but it has plenty of cherries on it so must have healed up all right. I said to Doc "I guess mother will feel pretty
bad to hear about this tree." - "I wouldn't tell her, if I were you," he said. "But I already have,"
Completed

I replied. "She would have to know it sometime and might as well first as last."

 Hope the news has not been too disturbing. I think very few cherry trees live to be over 30 years old and these are pretty close to that now.
  Must tell you about our store on wheels. It is a big blue truck - something like a bus. One of the Wheaton stores outfitted it and it goes the

rounds of our village stopping at certain corners and half way between corners at a specified time each day. When it stops
Completed

the driver blows a tremendous blast on his whistle and waits for his customers. They come from the houses nearest the stopping point and armed with carryall
boys, do their shopping.

 The truck has steps in front where you climb up. In the center is a line of shelves and also on each side. Trays for oranges and potatoes - Refrigerator at the

far end where you can find strawberries, butter, eggs, milk, cold drinks, cheese, etc.   The truck contains everything that a grocery
Completed

store carries - clothespins, candy, cornflakes - canned goods - vegetables - everything you can think of. No meat of course, though they do handle bacon squares.

 I have to get downtown before the bank closes (noon on Wed.) so must stop.
 Hope you are both well. What is your average daily temperature now?  It is 77 degrees today at 11 o'clock. 10 o'clock central time.
               Much love,    Katharine

on side:
?as Spears wife is being confined with her 7th child
Completed

June 19, '22.
Dearest Mum:

 Enclosed find check for X.
 Have been seeing some good movies lately. In one letter you spoke of intending to see "Mother O' Mine". I saw it here last month. I am enclosing

one of our programs so you can see what they are showing here. The ones marked with an X are especially good and if they get down your way, hope
you will both go and see them.

 Mrs. Curtis has not yet returned. Old Amos is on his deathbed and of course she
Completed

will remain for the funeral.

 I am getting used to playing and enjoy it very much. Have not nursed Marvin since the 5th and he is thriving nicely. Have had one or two real hot days -

up to 94. Last 2 or 3 have been cool.

 I saw Dos Spears on the street about a month ago and he said his wife was about to be confined. Imagine it.  7 children in 9 years.
  I hope the cherries came through all right.
Sorry about Mrs. Felt/ Will look that up about her stomach trouble and let you know.
  Malcolm in bed yesterday with stomach trouble. All right today. Too many cherries, I guess.
              Much love     Katharine
Completed

7-21-22 Glen Ellyn, Ill.
Tues. Eve.
Dear Mum & Grandmum:
Have a minute or two to write before show-time. Mrs. Curtis asked me to play this week. Her father died a day or so ago and will arrive here Friday
to be laid to rest with the other Churchills. 
XXX
Didn't have time to finish this last night so will start afresh. 
XXX
Thurs. aft. Try once more. Marvin is fine. No measles. We have a band in town now that plays at a band stand at Main St.
Completed

and Pa. Ave. They do very well for beginners. Took Malcolm over to hear them last Friday. Had a little time to spare before they began so walked up to old Mrs. Newton's. Found her sitting on the porch. Very glad to see me. Sat and talked for a while--then she showed me through the house, as I told her it was so long since I had been there I had forgotten what it looked like. She has a great big begonia in her living room window that I'm sure you would both like to see. It is the biggest one I ever saw.
Completed

The house is very large for an old lady like her to look after. She has John McNab and Ben Gault both with her. She seems pretty well. Complained of her stomach hurting sometimes. Says her late lamented husband left her only 95 c. a day to get on with. Says she has the house to live in as long as she needs it and a pension also, which help some. 
Marvin is quite a man by this time. Stands up alone and takes a step or two by holding onto things. When I am in the yard hanging up clothes I take him out and let him
Completed

crawl around. He generally comes over to the window that opens into the basement, then picks up bits of gravel and throws them into the old wash boiler that stands on the bench. 
In the kitchen there is a corner of the pantry where his jar of playthings stands. Rubber doll, rattle, clothes pins, an old top, etc. He is quite constructive for an infant, and takes pleasure in putting things into something rather than taking them out. He will sit contentedly
Completed

for a long time dropping clothespins into a milk bottle. He is tall enough now to take things off the kitchen table, holding to the edge meanwhile. Also sits in front of the gas stove and opens and shuts the lower door. Have taken several pictures of him and Malcolm. Roll has several not yet exposed. Will send you some when they are done.
No money yet. Expect to be able to send check some time this week. Business not so good lately.
Malcolm going downtown now so will send this
Completed

will mail you a copy of the new Glen Ellyn paper.
Much love  
Katharine
P.s. Mrs. Morse gave me some aster plants which I set out yesterday. Hope they will grow
Completed

[8-2-22]?   at depot

                 Sunday p.m.

Dear Folks:

 Am making my semi-annual trip to town going with Laura & Norine to dinner - then to see the Hotel Mouse, a musical comedy at the Palace.
 They were out to pick cherries a short time ago and Laura brot the baby a beautiful pair of tan shoes with white kid tops.

Just now saw Irene Rathbun. She is here at the depot with her little 8 year old girl. says she has been in G.E. since October but this is the 1st time I have seen her.
[[on side]
Marvin fine. Not caught measles yet.
Completed

Mrs. Curtis got back last Saturday and is playing at the show again. Did not hear whether her father died or not.  Your inclosure from Mrs. Thomas and Mrs. Wareham's
letter remind me of some news I forgot to mention. The younger Mrs. Wareham died about a month ago following the death of her baby who was either stillborn or
lived only a few hours. Mr. Wareham junior has just left for the west.

 I sold 3 bushels of late cherries to Mrs. Maurer (the neighbor in the Thomas house). charged $1.25 per. bu. not much, but enough
Completed

considering that Mr. Maurer did all the picking.  There are still quite a few left on the tree.

 Max is buying & selling printing machinery and expects to do quite well at it. He and a Mr. Getson are buying a nice auto together on the installment plan and they

are making trips to the nearby towns, calling on all the printers. His experience with the American Type Founders is very valuable in this line. This is on his own
hook, of course.

 Malcolm has been having the measles. The disease started when I wrote you he was in bed with stomach trouble. Did not have them hard and has been

up and around for
Completed

several days. Took the cards off the doors yesterday. Had to get them myself and put them on. Dr. Higby, the health officer, is sick an old slow poke. Had Dr. Schiele. 
He made 2 calls. Didn't think at first it was going to be measles. Found the nursing lecture on the subject quite helpful. Nothing in the N. C.? about fallen stomach
in connection with cancer of stomach. Tell Mrs. Felt to read Physical Culture magazine. Very helpful articles in it a la Dr Boffenmeyer.

 You said in a letter some months ago that Malcolm had had the measles, but he only had chicken pox, unless it was German measles you were thinking of and he has

not had that to my knowledge.

 Will send you a picture of new car. "Premier" chummy Roadster. 5 passenger.
                  Love,     K.
Completed

8-7-22

 Sunday P.M.

Dear Folks:

 Have been waiting to acknowledge my lovely present, so as to have some pictures to enclose. Guess you will know who each one is, so won't have to label them.
 The chemises are lovely. Something I had none of and fir perfectly. So pretty. The only trouble is no one can see them. Am wearing the one with the crocheted

yoke today. Got the shoulder straps fixed all right. Plenty long enough.

 Have a present coming to me from Margaret
Completed

which we will get today, when we will drive up to get some eggs she has for me (delivery by a Wheaton farmer lady) and will take her some apples.

 The 2nd apple tree (near the lilac bush) is crowded with apples this year. (Not a one last year from this tree.)  They are lovely and large and make splendid sauce and

pies. The skin is so thin they bruise easily and don't keep well, so I am using them up as fast as they fall. Have given away a lot to
Completed

Mrs. Kopp, Mrs. West, Mrs. Maurer, Mrs. McKay, and the Gilsons.

 Saw an article in the Physical Culture magazine for August entitled "How to cure appendicitis without the Knife" by Dr. Edwin F. Bowers, in which he speaks of

a Dr. Graham of New York, who gives treatments that cure alleged appendicitis, by manipulation. He speaks of one patient who had a lot of money and was
operated on for chronic appendicitis - cost her $4,000.00 and left a painful scar.
Completed

suffered the same afterward as she did before and the Drs. were going to operate again when it was discovered that her money was all gone - then this doctor
examined her and says "I found this woman to have a simple gastro-ptosis, or prolapse of the stomach, with spasm of the pylorus, radiating down the duodenum.
Five minutes manipulation restored this condition to normal and for four months there has been no return".

 I am quoting this because it seems sim
Completed

ilar to Mrs. Felt's case.  Perhaps you could call this to her attention. The P.C. Magazine is on sale practically everywhere and she would probably have no trouble securing
this copy. Another article in it, "The Remaking of my Sickly Family" gives quite complete suggestions for a proper diet so that if that is her trouble, she would have her cure
right before her in this magazine.

 I think you will enjoy reading the enclosed clipping about Amos Churchill. It mentions a few interesting points
Completed

on G.E. history.

 The new high school on honeysuckle hill is all ready for the laying of the cornerstone, of which you will see mention made in the paper I mailed you the other day.

Must stop now and do dishes.

 Many thank for you nice birthday letter, dear Mother.
  Much love,
    Katharine.
Completed

Marvin can climb all the way upstairs now without assistance or encouragement.
Then he waits at the top of the stairs to be helped down. Can go down one
step alone, but is
on side  series of numbers [probably baby's temp. taken often]

103 9/10 10:30
103 7/10 11:00
103 2/5   11;30
102 4/5   1:00
