8-22-22
Sunday, P.M.
Dear Mum:
Am getting impatient for a letter from you--fear the heat may have done you up. It has been awfully hot here up to a couple of days ago. Nice and cool today. Marvin had another fever spell last night--first he has had since that one in the spring. I didn't call the doctor but handled the case myself, according to previous experience. He is cutting 2 molars but do not know what else can have caused
Completed

the trouble as have been very careful about his eating, and his bowels are in good order apparently, all the time. I enclose temp. record. He was apparently normal today. It is amazing what a high fever he can have and show so little sign of it. Malcolm was sick last night, too so vibrated between them both. He complained of a headache and stomach ache and a bottle of castoria was half consumed between them. (the children). Dr. Baker called up last
Completed

Sunday--wanted to know how to get in touch with Max, so invited him out to dinner. He looks much the same--little more hardened, man o'the world air, almost looks the roué at times. His conversation is always amusing, however, so we enjoyed his visit. Elizabeth and her husband new baby and Barbara, are all living in a new bungalow in St. Paul, Minn., he says. He himself is staying at a hotel--I forget which one. He has a
Completed

new enterprise in view--the curing of eye-weakness, enabling everyone who takes his treatments to discard their eyeglasses, and see as well as formerly, no matter what their age. His arguments seem sound, and I think it may work. He no longer wears glasses and says his eyes are steadily improving. His cures are to be accomplished thru lectures on the subject, outlining exercises to be taken, and general care of the eyes. 
The apple crop this year is tremendous. We
Completed

are planning to have most of the snow apples made into cider. There is a place on the St. Charles Road where there is a cider mill--to convert apples into same at 4c per gallon. Have just finished reading Kate Douglas Wiggin's article in Sept. Companion, which I think you will enjoy. It makes me realize more strongly than ever how lucky I am to have a literary mother and father who spoke good English, read good books and taught me to do the same. I hope
Completed

I can do as well for my boys. It is a matter of great satisfaction to me that I have a good vocabulary and am "well spoken". It is the greatest thing I know of for making one feel at ease among strangers--or anywhere. 
I have sent for the pattern called the "Downtown dress" in the July No. of the W.H.C. and am going to try to get in town and purchase sufficient material to make 2 dresses like it. Have not decided what to get. It looks like an easy dress to make.
Am enjoying the chemises so much. 
Much love
Katharine
Completed

9-5-22
Sunday a.m.
Dear Mother:
I mentally wished you a happy birthday when I woke up this morning, and now I wish it again. I suppose you are baking your cake this very minute. Before I forget it, must explain about the Co-operative Society which I have intended to do many times before. All the co-op stores were bought in by Geo. Rasmussen nearly a year ago, and are now called National Tea Co. and are operated like all the other Nat'l stores. The one out here is under the supervision of Mr. Dempster, the man who
Completed

had charge of the Maywood and Oak Park stores when I was working there. The co-op. society is constantly being knocked and bucked by "big business" and always will be, I think, so is a poor investment. Better send for your 31 c. Am returning the card so you can do so. Have just discovered that I have no stamped envelopes left so guess this will have to be mailed Tuesday unless the office is open tomorrow morning. 

 Max is still in the same business which is gradually improving. Hope to have some money to send you soon.
Completed

There is a payment of $65.00 due on the car each month, which is quite an item. It is a lovely car, though, and essential to the business, besides. I had a lesson in driving it a couple of weeks ago. Drove about 10 miles. Expect to try again today. Had Papa out last Sunday. He had a fairly respectable outfit--new hat, palm beach suit. Took him for a ride over to Naperville which he said he had not visited since the time you and he went on your bicycles. HE said that the Rev. Hope Brown used to preach in
Completed

the congregational church there. 
I have started a dress, the material for which I got last Saturday. Got stuff for another dress, too, to be made in a different way from the same pattern. Hope can do a good job on them. Am making the linen one first--It has applique pockets of orange gingham, outlined in black buttonhole stitch. Also the colored binding around neck and sleeves. The gingham dress will be trimmed with dotted swiss. Samples enclosed.
Completed

Am mailing you some more copies of the village paper. One gives a sketch of the new high school as it is to be. It will stand on Honeysuckle Hill, visible from the walk just after you pass the house where the evergreen hedge used to be. 
Can't find your last letter so do not remember what questions you asked. 
In another letter you spoke of Mrs. Thomas. She is very thin, but seems well. She works hard all the time, and does not apparently get out any oftener than she used to. Arthur is still
Completed

small for his age, but seems well and happy. He comes over occasionally to play with Malcolm. M. has learned the Thomas telephone number, and for a while he used to call up nearly every day, all by himself.
Awfully hot the past few days. I closed the house up early this morning and will try to keep it cool. 
I enclose picture taken by Laura on our picnic in Wash Pk July 4th. Also another of the auto to replace the one with a hole in it. Hope you both are well and can shed the heat. 
Much love
Katharine
Completed

P.S.--Monday. P.M.
P.O. closed so have time to write more. Saw Ruth Stubbings a couple of weeks ago. She was here with her youngest little girl (about 3 years old) (she has 2 other girls) visiting Eva Clare. She looks just as she always did, except that she is thiner, and has (or had when I saw her) a couple of unattractive carbuncles, a gift from her dad, no doubt. 
Her child is very homely. Too bad; for Ruth really
Completed

is bright enough. But she combs her hair in a very severe fashion and delights in being quite rough and ready, as she always did. I noticed some scrofula marks on her neck, same as Florence used to have. 
Did I tell you Florence Mayland has a baby, a boy, born the 3rd of August? Have not been to see her yet. 
The Scotts, Norine and we are planning a picnic to Crystal Lake next Sunday. It will be our first swim this year.
Completed

Wednesday P.M. 
9-28-22
Dear Folks:
Our cool nights have begun 45 degree symbol early in the morning, so I suppose you are also having a breathing spell. 
Had a visit from Mr. Blake last Friday. He notified me earlier in the week that he was coming, and I had a nice little visit with him for an hour or so. He called on Mrs. Hall, then on his way back (I walked over there with him) I accompanied him to the electric station and waited until his car came. He is quite forgetful, but seems the same as he did when I was a child, in other-
Completed

respects. I spoke of you and Grandma returning from Florida with me when Malcolm was a baby and of your both being here for a time--and he said--"I didn't know they were here. Why wasn't I told?" 
Then just a few minutes later he was telling of his visit out here with Miss Hughes at that very time--which will give you an idea of his mental idiosyncrasies. 
I gave the books their semiannual dusting yesterday and they look much improved. 
Malcolm could not start in school this fall as they
Completed

are very strict about taking only those who will be 6 by the 1st of January. I am teaching him at home, however, and he can enter the class either this winter, if they form a midyear class, or this next fall. Mr. Butler, the principal, said he could enter 2nd grade next year if I can coach him and have him keep up with the class. 
I am teaching him what all the letters "say" (the sounds) The letters themselves he knows very well both small and large, as the typewriter taught him the small ones. I gave him his first writing
Completed

lesson this morning, showing him how to write the latter "a". He is also learning how to tell time--and I am working hard on his music. I am disappointed to find that it is almost impossible for him to carry a tune. I have worked and worked over a phrase of music containing only 3 or 4 notes, trying to get him to sing them properly, but he continually gets off the key. He knows the different songs when he hears them, but can only approximate the tunes himself. 
I have two roomers--one in each back room. Pre-
Completed

some they will not be here later than the 1st of November or they will get frozen out. Both are carpenters--rather elderly. One has a family in Rockford and goes home for the weekend. The other's children are all grown and married. Am making use of him this afternoon to fix my windows. Cords need replacing in the north room and the kitchen. Marvin is howling so must stop.
He had a bad fever spell again last week while getting part of two upper molars. He always has these same spells while teething--runs a fever from 101-104--and
Completed

takes nothing but orange juice and water. Gets quite thin and gradually recovers. Do not know of anything but the teeth that could possibly cause it. Am very particular about his diet all the time. 
He is fine now. Hope he will continue so until the eye teeth arrive. They are not due until the 18th month, which will give us a period of comparative calm.
Much love
Katharine
Completed

10-12-22
Monday Evening
Dear Mum:
Took a walk with Margaret and Betty this afternoon down to view the new high school. Couldn't see much from the sidewalk and road was too torn up to get the baby buggies nearer. The Flett family arrived a little before the first of the month and are living in the Wareham house. They find it rather close quarters after their Wheaton place and there is much to be done in the way of cleaning and varnishing They have a lease for a year.
Completed

Have just got our first coal in for the winter. 11.00 per ton. a dollar more than it was last year. Hope to have about $20.00 to send you this week--then will try to be regular hereafter. 
Arthur's letter is very good. Am going to teach Malcolm regular handwriting rather than printing. The printing is all right for learning the letters, and he can make them all just as Arthur can, but for word building I prefer him to use regular script. There is too much to unlearn the other way. 
I sing the fingerplay
Completed

songs with him every day. He enjoys them very much and I think he is improving in singing. The "phrase" I mentioned was part of a song, the marching one from "a dozen and two"--"now to our songs and games march along"--
I shall be interested to hear your opinion of the Galsworthy book. I think "In Chancery" was the best one.
Mrs. West brought over a very pretty bouquet today--3 big pink dahlias. 3 multi-colored petunias, and a red geranium.
Completed

They make the dining table look quite dressed up. 
Did I tell you I got "If Winter Comes" from the library, some time ago? It is very good--a bit depressing in places, but very well written, I think. The title comes from Shelley--"Oh wind, if winter comes, can spring be far behind?" 
Have read most of Alice in Wonderland to Malcolm, which he enjoys very much. Have also read most of "What Tommy Did" and one
Completed

of the stories from Miss Alcott's "Aunt Jo's Scrap Bag".
Marvin walks lots now--nearly all the time. Have not weighed him for a long time. Will take him to the scales  at the depot sometime soon, and let you know what it is. 
Have not seen nor heard from Helen for a long time will have to drive over and see them. She and her father had some birthdays not long ago. Did you remember? 
Hope Grandma is well. Have not forgotten about the table you want, but
Completed

Max is away so much of the time it is rather hard to get things done. Afraid my carpenter roomer would not make a good job of it. Rather botched the other one.
Marvin is cutting his stomach teeth. Believe the last fever was caused by their starting, together with the molars. He is so tired of zwieback now and wont eat it I give him bread that has been dried off in the oven, and graham crackers. Eats all kinds of fruit, apples, pears, peaches and grapes. 
Love,
Katharine
Completed

Oct. 18, 1922.

Dear Mum:
More hard luck instead of money. Max was held up and robbed of $50.00 the other evening. Six months ago he lost $90.00 in a similar experience. Did not mention it at the time, as I know you have enough troubles of your own without listening to a recital of other peoples! He is thinking of giving up the work he is in now and taking an offer he has had with the American Aluminum Ware Co. which would pay $35.00 per week and expenses, also commissions on all sales.
Completed

He says it should amount to 75.00 per week at least. His territory would be Indiana, and they would pay railroad fare, so he would keep the car for recreation only. It is getting so holdups are as thick as fleas on a dog, and it is unwise to carry more than a few dollars with you.
We are having the house painted. Grey, 2 coats. Looks very nice--goes better with the red roof than the brown did. It is nearly done. Porch floor is dry so we can walk on it. Kept the dogs off by making
Completed

a barricade of the porch swing and some door screens. Frosty today--30 degree symbol at 7 a.m. Winter apple tree looks beautiful. 
Max has made a driveway in the rear by filling in the ditch at the alley, so we get the coal in that way now instead of across the lot to the west which of course is now inaccessible. 
Am using some of my room rent money for some Christmas photos of myself and the kids. I enclosed one of the proofs which you may keep.
Completed

Am expecting Margaret up to take a walk. 
Will mail you some more Glen Ellyans today. 
You will scarcely believe it, but they say G.E. now has 400 more people than Wheaton. Whenever you go down town the streets are lined with cars. Dr. Boughman said this morning he counted 37 (not on a Saturday) on Crescent Blvd alone, in the downtown district (These are parked cars, not moving ones).
Understan some of Dr. Saunders' former wives have bobbed up to claim part of the estate. Mrs. S. vacationing in Mich. Geo. S. glum as usual, still fighting. 
Much love
Katharine
Completed

Glen Ellyn, Ill.
Oct. 20, 1922.
Dear Mum:
I am hurrying up to answer your letter for two reasons. First, I forgot to enclose the proof in my other one and second I want Mrs. Butler's address so I can get in touch with Kate. There are so many Butlers in Oak Park, according to the telephone book, and I do not know her first name or initials. 
I want Kate to pay me a visit before she goes south. I always enjoyed her very much.
Have written her at
Completed

the old address she gave me, but doubt it will be delivered. Can you let me have that right away, so I can see her before they leave?
So kind of you to remember Max's birthday. He appreciates it very much indeed. 
Must hurry and put this out for the postman. 
Your egg price is the same as ours, though I paid 60 c. last week for fresh eggs. (Mrs. Higgins)
Much love
Katharine
Completed

Front of cancelled postcard dated November 28 1922
Mrs May Walden
Avon Park
Fla
Completed

Tuesday. A.M.
Dear Mother:
No tenant yet. May not be able to leave before Jan. 1st. Will mail your coats. Have had a few snow flurries. Warmer today and bright sun. 34degree symbol at noon.
Mrs. Kopp has a washer just like ours. Bought it about a year ago. Also has cleaner and a new car--a Durant. She drives it herself. Had no env. in house. Hence this card. 
Much love
Katharine
